CLASS ACTION COMPLAINT 
 
 

Case 3:15-cv-00623-JST   Document 1   Filed 02/09/15   Page 3 of 26
1  Plaintiffs Kevin Hart, Nina Silva-Collins and Lee Harris, by and through their attorneys, 
2  bring this action on behalf of themselves and all others similarly situated, against Carolyn W. 
3  Colvin in her official capacity as Acting Commissioner of Social Security (“Defendant”), and 
4  allege as follows: 
5  INTRODUCTION 
6  1.  Plaintiffs bring this class action to challenge Defendant’s reliance on consultative 
7  examinations (CEs), performed by a physician who is now disqualified, in denying or terminating 
8  disability benefits.  This physician, Dr. Frank Chen, routinely submitted reports that were not 
9  based on medically acceptable clinical diagnostic techniques.  As numerous complaints from 
10  applicants demonstrate, Dr. Chen’s CE reports contained false statements and were based on 
11  cursory examinations and inadequate communication with his patients.  These CE reports were 
12  then relied upon, in whole or in part, to deny or terminate Supplemental Security Income (SSI) 
13  and/or Social Security Disability Insurance (SSDI) to Plaintiffs and members of the proposed 
14  class.  By this action, Plaintiffs seek the reopening of prior determinations where Defendant relied 
15  on a report by Dr. Chen, and the opportunity to receive a new CE from a well-qualified clinician. 
16  2.  In order to qualify for benefits based on disability under either SSI or SSDI, an 
17  individual must be unable “to engage in any substantial gainful activity by reason of any 
18  medically determinable physical or mental impairment which can be expected to result in death or 
19  which has lasted or can be expected to last for a continuous period of not less than 12 months[.]”  
20  42 U.S.C. § 423(d)(1)(A).  
21  3.  The Social Security Act and the regulations promulgated thereunder require that 
22  Defendant “need[s] evidence from acceptable medical sources to establish whether [an individual 
23  has] a medically determinable impairment.”  20 C.F.R. §§ 404.1513(a), 416.913(a). 
24  4.  In order to have adequate medical evidence of an individual’s disabilities, it is 
25  frequently necessary to procure a CE from a qualified medical source.  20 C.F.R. § 404.1517 et 
26  seq.   
27  5.  For many years, Dr. Chen performed a large volume of these CEs in San Francisco 
28  and surrounding counties.  He regularly issued reports that he knew were incorrect or incomplete, 
CLASS ACTION COMPLAINT  1 
 
 

Case 3:15-cv-00623-JST   Document 1   Filed 02/09/15   Page 4 of 26
1  including statements that he performed tests he did not in fact perform and conclusions that were 
2  inconsistent with medical evidence already in the record, with no explanation or even 
3  acknowledgement of the inconsistency. 
4  6.  On the basis of numerous complaints from applicants and their representatives 
5  over a period of years, Dr. Chen was disqualified from continuing to provide CEs as of December 
6  30, 2013.  His CE reports, however, continue to be treated as competent evidence by the Social 
7  Security Administration (SSA) and used in determinations to deny or terminate SSI and SSDI 
8  benefits.  20 C.F.R. §§ 404.1503a, 416.903a. 
9  7.  Plaintiffs challenge Defendant’s policy and practice of relying on Dr. Chen’s 
10  defective CE reports in denying or terminating disability benefits, in violation of its requirement 
11  to base such determinations on evidence from acceptable medical sources. 
12  8.  SSA regulations also require that Defendant monitor and ensure the adequacy of 
13  the CE process and providers.  42 U.S.C. § 421(j)(3); 20 C.F.R. §§ 404.1519s(g), 416.919s(g).  
14  Defendant’s policy and practice of relying on Dr. Chen’s defective CE reports in denying or 
15  terminating disability benefits is contrary to this mandate. 
16  9.  SSDI and SSI applicants and beneficiaries represent a population with education 
17  levels well below the national average.  These individuals are almost never represented by 
18  counsel during the application process or on reconsideration, which is the first phase of the 
19  administrative appeal process.   
20  10.  Plaintiffs and class members were neither notified of the disqualification of 
21  Dr. Chen nor provided copies of his reports at the time of their denial or termination.  
22  Accordingly, they had no basis for knowing that their disability determinations were based in part 
23  on incorrect, incomplete medical reports.    
24  JURISDICTION AND VENUE 
25  11.  This Court has jurisdiction pursuant to 42 U.S.C. § 405(g). 
26  12.  Venue in this Court is proper pursuant to 42 U.S.C. § 405(g) because at least one 
27  named Plaintiff resides within the Northern District of California. 
28 
CLASS ACTION COMPLAINT  2 
 
 

Case 3:15-cv-00623-JST   Document 1   Filed 02/09/15   Page 5 of 26
1  PARTIES 
2  13.  Plaintiff Kevin Hart is a resident of San Mateo County who receives SSI and SSDI 
3  benefits and is facing termination of his benefits after a consultative examination by Dr. Chen. 
4  14.  Plaintiff Nina Silva-Collins is a resident of Alameda County who was denied SSI 
5  after a consultative examination by Dr. Chen. 
6  15.  Plaintiff Lee Harris is a resident of Alameda County who was denied SSI after a 
7  consultative examination by Dr. Chen. 
8  16.  Defendant Carolyn W. Colvin is the Acting Commissioner of Social Security, 
9  charged by federal law with administering and supervising all benefit programs administered by 
10  SSA nationwide, including SSI and SSDI.  The Commissioner is responsible for determining 
11  eligibility for SSI and SSDI benefits and is authorized to reopen and review these determinations.  
12  She is sued in her official capacity as the official charged with performing the statutory and 
13  regulatory duties of SSA and its divisions, agents, employees and representatives. 
14  INDIVIDUAL PLAINTIFF ALLEGATIONS 
15  Plaintiff Kevin Hart 
16  17.  Plaintiff Kevin Hart is a fifty year old man who was struck by a car on October 2, 
17  2007, shattering his right leg.  Mr. Hart underwent two surgeries in the following months to 
18  attempt to repair his leg, but still experiences tremendous pain and limited mobility.  His leg 
19  injury has also resulted in related ankle and leg pain, and the growth of cysts on his feet.  He 
20  needs a cane to walk.  The resulting decrease in mobility has also caused other health effects, 
21  such as increased blood pressure and cholesterol and swelling in the feet.  He also suffers from 
22  diabetes and emphysema.  Mr. Hart suffers substantial pain and is significantly limited in his day-
23  to-day activities.  He cannot stand or sit for long periods of time. 
24  18.  While he wants to be able to work, Mr. Hart is incapable of sustained employment 
25  due to his medical conditions.  Mr. Hart worked from the time he was a teenager until his 
26  accident.  He started out doing construction, carpentry, painting and roofing.  He spent a number 
27  of years working for GMG, a Port of San Francisco janitorial contractor.  Then he worked as a 
28  loader for Blue Diamond Growers in Sacramento, California, and then as a groundskeeper for Cal 
CLASS ACTION COMPLAINT  3 
 
 

Case 3:15-cv-00623-JST   Document 1   Filed 02/09/15   Page 6 of 26
1  Expo in Sacramento, until his accident in 2007.  Mr. Hart attempted to return to his job at Cal 
2  Expo in 2008 after the two surgeries and extensive physical therapy.  He had to stop working 
3  after less than a week because he was physically unable to perform the duties of the job. He also 
4  contacted Blue Diamond Growers about returning to work there; however, he could not return to 
5  the job because he was again physically unable to perform the duties of a loader. 
6  19.  Immediately after the accident, Mr. Hart underwent open reduction internal 
7  fixation (ORIF) surgery to try to repair his ankle fracture, where hardware (an “internal fixation” 
8  device) is placed on the bone. 
9  20.  In a June 2008 medical report, a doctor from UC Davis Medical Center explained 
10  that Mr. Hart probably suffered from a “non-union of the fibular site that was very painful” and 
11  while his ankle “would improve somewhat over time,” Mr. Hart “would likely have abnormalities 
12  in terms of decreased range of motion and abnormal gait related to his injury.” 
13  21.  The hardware in Mr. Hart’s ankle was surgically removed on June 18, 2008, 
14  leaving him with residual pain and stiffness.  At an August 18, 2008 consultation, Mr. Hart 
15  presented with “occasional sharp shooting pain” and “leg swelling on extensive walking.”   
16  22.  Medical records from UC Davis Medical Center and Sacramento County DHHS 
17  show that Mr. Hart was also diagnosed with emphysema, hypertension, and eczema in late 2008, 
18  and insomnia in early 2010. 
19  23.  On April 23, 2010, an Administrative Law Judge (“ALJ”) found Mr. Hart to be 
20  disabled with an onset established retroactive to 2007, due to his history of right ankle fracture, 
21  emphysema, and hypertension.  Mr. Hart was assessed to have “less than sedentary residual 
22  functional capacity.” 
23  24.  Then, on April 12, 2013, Mr. Hart was violently attacked by a group of teenagers 
24  in San Francisco.  He sustained a non-displaced rib fracture, a serious kidney laceration with 
25  hematoma, ruptured cyst, and multiple abrasions.  After the attack he urinated blood.  The 
26  hospital examination also revealed that Mr. Hart suffered from polycystic kidney disease. 
27  25.  Mr. Hart’s medical records show that, independent of his injuries from the attack, 
28  Mr. Hart’s health declined in many respects after he was found to be disabled.  Progress notes 
CLASS ACTION COMPLAINT  4 
 
 

Case 3:15-cv-00623-JST   Document 1   Filed 02/09/15   Page 7 of 26
1  from his treatment at San Mateo Medical Center in 2013 showed that Mr. Hart had a mass on his 
2  right foot that was diagnosed as plantar fibromatosis.  The 2013 records also note new problems 
3  with Mr. Hart’s foot, including a “nodule at plantar to forefoot/midfoot, along the medial margin 
4  of plantar fascia.”  Mr. Hart was also diagnosed with “polcycstic kidney NOS; Diabetes Mellitus, 
5  Type II;” “Hyperlipidemia and Plantar Fibromatosis.”  After the attack, Mr. Hart developed 
6  debilitating back pain. 
7  26.  In 2013, SSA notified Mr. Hart that he was scheduled for a continuing disability 
8  review (CDR) to determine if he continued to meet the disability standard.  The CDR differs from 
9  the initial disability determination in that the first step is to determine if there has been any 
10  medical improvement since the date he was first determined to be disabled.  If medical 
11  improvement related to ability to do work cannot be established, and no exceptions apply, 
12  benefits will continue.  20 C.F.R. § 404.1594. 
13  27.  As part of his CDR, Mr. Hart was referred to Dr. Chen for a consultative 
14  examination, which he received on August 15, 2013. 
15  28.  Dr. Chen’s entire examination of Mr. Hart lasted approximately ten minutes. 
16  29.  Dr. Chen did not complete a full physical examination of Mr. Hart.  He asked 
17  Mr. Hart about his condition, but when Mr. Hart attempted to explain the diagnosis he had 
18  received from his doctors during his hospitalization, Dr. Chen repeatedly interrupted him by 
19  asking “who told you that?”  It appears that Dr. Chen did not review Mr. Hart’s medical records, 
20  which would have corroborated his explanations of his ailments.  Dr. Chen did not show any 
21  interest in learning about Mr. Hart’s condition. 
22  30.  In a subsequent report entitled “Comprehensive Internal Medicine Evaluation,” 
23  dated August 15, 2013, Dr. Chen incorrectly identified Mr. Hart’s “Chief Complaint” as 
24  “Hypertension” and “Intermittent shortness of breath.”  His only two diagnoses were 
25  “[h]ypertension,” and “symptoms of intermittent shortness of breath on exertion.”   
26  31.  Dr. Chen’s report claims that he completed tests that he did not in fact perform.  
27  The report gave results for numerous range of motion tests that would have required Dr. Chen to 
28  physically manipulate Mr. Hart’s body.  However, Dr. Chen did not touch Mr. Hart’s body with 
CLASS ACTION COMPLAINT  5 
 
 

Case 3:15-cv-00623-JST   Document 1   Filed 02/09/15   Page 8 of 26
1  his hands during the examination, ask him to lie down on the examination table, or ask him to 
2  remove his clothes or shoes.  He did not perform standard tests for strength or range of motion.  
3  He did not perform even basic tests, such as listening to Mr. Hart’s chest with a stethoscope.   
4  32.  Neither Dr. Chen’s diagnoses nor his functional capacity assessment include any 
5  mention of Mr. Hart’s leg.  Dr. Chen completely omitted Mr. Hart’s leg and feet ailments from 
6  these sections, despite the fact that Mr. Hart arrived at his CE with his cane, an assistive device.  
7  Dr. Chen briefly looked at the scar on Mr. Hart’s leg, but only after Mr. Hart proactively 
8  described his surgeries.  He asked Mr. Hart to stand on his right leg while lifting his left leg.  
9  When Mr. Hart responded that he was physically unable to stand one-legged on his right leg, 
10  Dr. Chen had him sit down and hit his knees with a hammer to test his reflexes.  He did not 
11  perform any additional examination or test of Mr. Hart’s ability to stand or walk.  He did not at 
12  any point observe Mr. Hart walking without his cane.   
13  33.  Dr. Chen concluded that Mr. Hart was capable of standing and walking for six 
14  hours in an eight hour day, and sitting for six hours in an eight hour day.   He opined that 
15  Mr. Hart could carry “50 pounds occasionally and 2 pounds frequently.”  Mr. Hart, however, 
16  cannot stand or walk for more than a few minutes without the assistance of a cane, and he cannot 
17  sit for long periods of time without experiencing painful swelling in his feet.   
18  34.  After Dr. Chen’s evaluation, Mr. Hart received a notice from SSA dated 
19  September 11, 2013 telling him that his benefits were being terminated because he was no longer 
20  disabled.  He did not receive a copy of the CE report.  He promptly filed a Request for 
21  Reconsideration on September 30, 2013, stating “I am disabled. The doctor that I was sent to did 
22  not examine me.”  A hearing was scheduled for February 26, 2014 before a Disability Hearing 
23  Officer.  He was not represented by counsel at the Reconsideration hearing.  Although Dr. Chen 
24  had been disqualified two months before the hearing, neither SSA nor Disability Determination 
25  Service Division of the California Department of Social Services (DDSD) ever notified him of 
26  Dr. Chen’s disqualification. 
27  35.  In a written order dated March 17, 2014, the Disability Hearing Officer found that 
28  Mr. Hart’s physical impairments had “medically improved” since the Comparison Point Decision 
CLASS ACTION COMPLAINT  6 
 
 

Case 3:15-cv-00623-JST   Document 1   Filed 02/09/15   Page 9 of 26
1  (CPD) and that he is no longer disabled.  The Order specifically cited Dr. Chen’s report for its 
2  opinion that “the claimant is able to do medium work activities.”  Despite the fact that Mr. Hart 
3  had submitted evidence from another doctor concluding Mr. Hart had “limitations approximate to 
4  less than sedentary work ability,” the Order found that Dr. Chen’s opinion “is more reasonable as 
5  consistent and supported by medical evidence.” 
6  36.  On March 25, 2014, Mr. Hart filed a Request for Hearing by an ALJ.  He is 
7  awaiting his hearing. 
8  37.  Mr. Hart currently lives with his seventy-eight-year-old mother in San Mateo.  He 
9  tries to help his mother with chores around the house but his disability makes simple tasks, like 
10  doing the dishes, extremely difficult.  He worries about having enough money to meet basic needs 
11  like paying rent and buying food, let alone paying for the special shoes and inserts that his doctor 
12  has prescribed to take care of his feet.  He struggles to get by with his monthly SSI and SSDI 
13  disability benefits, and cannot imagine how he will meet these basic life necessities without it.  
14  That monthly benefit is his only income. 
15  Plaintiff Nina Silva-Collins 
16  38.  Plaintiff Nina Silva-Collins is a thirty-eight year old woman who suffers from 
17  severe, chronic anemia caused by menorrhagia (abnormally heavy and prolonged menstrual 
18  bleeding), lumbar degenerative disc disease, depression, anxiety, asthma, and hypertension. 
19  39.  Menorrhagia is Ms. Silva-Collins’ most debilitating condition, resulting in a period 
20  of intense bleeding that can last up to three weeks per menstrual cycle.  She has been hospitalized 
21  repeatedly as a result, and treated with blood transfusions and medication.  She brings a change of 
22  clothes everywhere she goes because she bleeds so heavily.  When she is menstruating, she has to 
23  go to the restroom once an hour.  This makes even sedentary work impossible.  
24  40.  Ms. Silva-Collins applied for SSI and SSDI benefits on September 7, 2011, when 
25  her condition required multiple blood transfusions at St. Rose Hospital in Hayward, California.  
26  Her claim was denied initially on February 8, 2012.  Ms. Silva-Collins filed a timely request for 
27  reconsideration on February 16, 2012, which was denied on July 19, 2012.  Ms. Silva-Collins 
28 
CLASS ACTION COMPLAINT  7 
 
 

Case 3:15-cv-00623-JST   Document 1   Filed 02/09/15   Page 10 of 26
1  filed a written request for a hearing on August 13, 2012.  A hearing before an ALJ was held on 
2  July 2, 2013, but a supplemental hearing was set when the ALJ determined that a CE was needed. 
3  41.  On August 10, 2013, Ms. Silva-Collins was examined by Dr. Chen at the Bay 
4  View Medical Clinic in Oakland, California. 
5  42.  Dr. Chen’s entire examination lasted approximately ten minutes.   
6  43.  Dr. Chen did not complete a full physical examination of Ms. Silva-Collins.  He 
7  lifted Ms. Silva-Collins’ leg, and asked her to bend over and squat.   Dr. Chen asked her how 
8  much she could pick up, and she explained that her ability to lift items varied due to the cyclical 
9  menorrhagia.  Ms. Silva-Collins’ vital signs were not taken, nor did Dr. Chen use a stethoscope to 
10  listen to her heart beat.  Dr. Chen did not use a hammer or other instrument to test her reflexes, 
11  and he did not test her grip or strength.  Ms. Silva-Collins was never asked to remove her clothes, 
12  shoes or socks, and her body was not measured or palpated.  Dr. Chen did not ask Ms. Silva-
13  Collins any questions about her menorrhagia, anemia, or other blood issues, or the effect that 
14  these chronic conditions had on her physical capabilities. 
15  44.  In a subsequent report, titled “Comprehensive Internal Medicine Evaluation,” 
16  Dr. Chen made only two diagnoses: “[l]ow back pain, possibly due to obesity,” and “obesity.”  
17  Neither his diagnoses nor the functional capacity assessment mention Ms. Silva-Collins’ 
18  menorrhagia or anemia.   
19  45.  Dr. Chen’s report claims that he completed tests that he did not in fact perform.  
20  The report gave results for numerous strength and range of motion tests that he did not perform. 
21  46.  Dr. Chen concluded, as he did with Mr. Hart, that Ms. Silva-Collins was capable 
22  of standing and walking for six hours in an eight hour day, and sitting for six hours in an eight 
23  hour day.  He opined that she could occasionally bend, stoop, and crouch, and warned only that 
24  Ms. Silva-Collins should “avoid climbing ladders and scaffolds.”   
25  47.  Following the supplemental hearing on January 8, 2014, the ALJ denied her claim 
26  for benefits in a written order dated January 16, 2014.  In concluding that Ms. Silva-Collins was 
27  not disabled, the ALJ gave “great weight to the opinion of consultative examiner Dr. Chen” and 
28  noted “[h]is examination is the most thorough and detailed in the record, and well supported by 
CLASS ACTION COMPLAINT  8 
 
 

Case 3:15-cv-00623-JST   Document 1   Filed 02/09/15   Page 11 of 26
1  the medical evidence as a whole, thus, the undersigned gives his opinion great weight to the 
2  extent that it is consistent with this decision.” 
3  48.  Ms. Silva-Collins was never notified by SSA or DDSD of Dr. Chen’s 
4  disqualification as a consultative examiner. 
5  49.  Upon learning of Dr. Chen’s disqualification as a consultative examiner, 
6  Ms. Silva-Collins’ attorney sent a letter on February 12, 2014 to the ALJ, attaching a letter from 
7  the California Department of Social Services explaining that Dr. Chen had been disqualified, and 
8  asking the ALJ to reconsider the unfavorable decision.  This request was denied. 
9  50.  Ms. Silva-Collins filed an appeal to the SSA Appeals Council, and is currently 
10  awaiting their decision.   
11  51.  Ms. Silva-Collins is incapable of sustained employment due to her medical 
12  conditions.  While she has had some temporary, unskilled jobs—an assembly line worker from 
13  January to June 2011, and a warehouse worker with United Parcel Service between June 2000 
14  and February 2003—her highest lifetime earnings in any single year was $6,321 in 2001.  
15  Ms. Silva-Collins has no high school diploma or GED, and no other skills or means to earn a 
16  living. 
17  52.  Ms. Silva-Collins currently lives with her father and survives on CalFresh (food 
18  stamps) and $336 a month in General Assistance, much of which she gives to her father in 
19  exchange for his support.  Ms. Silva-Collins has applied for Medi-Cal, but that application is 
20  currently pending.  SSI would allow Ms. Silva-Collins a measure of independence and stability, 
21  and a means to afford needed medical supplies (such as heavy-duty menstrual pads) and other life 
22  necessities. 
23  Plaintiff Lee Harris 
24  53.  Plaintiff Lee Harris is a fifty-four year old man who has suffered from debilitating 
25  pain since a car accident in April 2005 during which he fractured both of his ankles and injured 
26  his lower back.  A CT scan at the time of the accident revealed multiple transverse process 
27  fractures involving the lower thoracic spine and lumbar spine.  On April 13, 2005, Mr. Harris had 
28  surgery to repair the fractures in his right heel bone and left foot that left him in a short leg cast.  
CLASS ACTION COMPLAINT  9 
 
 

Case 3:15-cv-00623-JST   Document 1   Filed 02/09/15   Page 12 of 26
1  The next week, he underwent another surgical repair to repin the right heel bone fracture and the 
2  screw in his left foot fracture. 
3  54.  The hardware in his right heel bone caused continued, debilitating pain, and 
4  Mr. Harris had another surgery to remove it in January 2006. 
5  55.  Mr. Harris is incapable of sustained employment due to his medical conditions.  
6  Before his accident, Mr. Harris worked as an auto dismantler for Dorris Auto Wreckers.  
7  Mr. Harris has also worked in warehousing, anodizing, and construction.  While he wants to be 
8  able to work again, he is in too much pain. 
9  56.  Mr. Harris applied for SSI benefits on August 9, 2011.  SSA referred Mr. Harris to 
10  Dr. Chen for a consultative examination, which he received on October 28, 2011. 
11  57.  Mr. Harris was examined by Dr. Chen at the Bay View Medical Clinic in Oakland, 
12  California.  Mr. Harris was accompanied by his son, who was approximately six or seven years 
13  old at the time. 
14  58.  Dr. Chen’s entire examination lasted approximately twelve minutes.   
15  59.  Dr. Chen did not complete a full physical examination of Mr. Harris.  He asked 
16  Mr. Harris to take off his socks and shoes.  Dr. Chen looked at Mr. Harris’ feet.  Dr. Chen did not 
17  use a hammer or other instrument to test his feet. 
18  60.  Dr. Chen asked Mr. Harris to stand without his cane.  Mr. Harris attempted to 
19  stand, but he had to grab the examination table immediately.  Dr. Chen told him to stop grabbing 
20  the table, to which Mr. Harris responded that he could not. 
21  61.  Mr. Harris took out his medications to show Dr. Chen, but the doctor said that he 
22  did not need to see them and asked no questions about them.  Dr. Chen did not ask Mr. Harris any 
23  questions about his conditions or his physical capabilities. 
24  62.  Dr. Chen’s report claims that he completed tests that he did not in fact perform.  
25  The report gave results for numerous range of motion tests that would have required Dr. Chen to 
26  physically manipulate Mr. Harris’s body. However, Dr. Chen did not touch Mr. Harris’s body 
27  during the examination.  He did not perform standard tests for strength or range of motion.  He 
28  did not perform even basic tests, such as listening to Mr. Harris’s chest with a stethoscope. 
CLASS ACTION COMPLAINT  10 
 
 

Case 3:15-cv-00623-JST   Document 1   Filed 02/09/15   Page 13 of 26
1  63.  Dr. Chen concluded that Mr. Harris did not need to use his cane to walk short 
2  distances, even though he had never seen Mr. Harris stand without it.  Dr. Chen also concluded 
3  that Mr. Harris could sit for six hours, stand and walk for six hours in an eight-hour workday, lift 
4  and carry 25 pounds frequently, and lift and carry 50 pounds occasionally. 
5  64.  Mr. Harris’s application was denied on November 18, 2011, and again upon 
6  reconsideration on May 16, 2012.  Thereafter, Mr. Harris filed a written request for hearing on 
7  June 19, 2012.  That hearing was held before an ALJ on April 29, 2013. 
8  65.  In a written order dated June 4, 2013, the ALJ determined that Mr. Harris has the 
9  residual functional capacity to perform medium work as defined in 20 C.F.R. § 416.967(c).  The 
10  decision states that “the examination by Dr. Chen indicates far greater functionality than alleged 
11  by the claimant.”  The ALJ “assign[ed] the greatest weight to Dr. Chen’s opinion because he 
12  personally examined the claimant.” 
13  66.  Mr. Harris applied again for SSI benefits on November 14, 2013. 
14  67.  On November 14, 2013, Mr. Harris’s counsel arranged a physical and forensic 
15  examination of Mr. Harris by Dr. Emily Cohen.  Dr. Cohen diagnosed Mr. Harris with chronic 
16  lumbosacral pain, chronic ankle/foot pain, acute left forearm pain, and hypertension.  Dr. Cohen 
17  concluded that Mr. Harris could walk and/or stand for about two hours out of an eight-hour work 
18  day, and sit for six hours out of an eight-hour work day.  Given his instability, Dr. Cohen found 
19  that Mr. Harris could only lift and carry about ten pounds frequently and occasionally. 
20  68.  On July 21, 2014, SSA referred Mr. Harris to Dr. Calvin Pon for a consultative 
21  examination, which he received on August 8, 2014.  Mr. Harris was examined by Dr. Pon at the 
22  Bay View Medical Clinic in Oakland, California.  Dr. Pon similarly diagnosed Mr. Harris with 
23  chronic low back pain and chronic bilateral heel-foot pain. 
24  69.  Mr. Harris’s claim was denied initially on August 28, 2014.  This initial 
25  determination stated that Mr. Harris’s CE was “reviewed and compared with CE by Dr. Chen in 
26  prior file.”  Mr. Harris sent a request for reconsideration on September 12, 2014, which was 
27  denied on January 26, 2015.  Mr. Harris filed a written request for a hearing on February 4, 2015.  
28  That request is pending. 
CLASS ACTION COMPLAINT  11 
 
 

Case 3:15-cv-00623-JST   Document 1   Filed 02/09/15   Page 14 of 26
1  70.  Mr. Harris lives alone in an apartment in Oakland, California.  His disability 
2  makes simple tasks extremely difficult.  For example, Mr. Harris has to depend on others to do 
3  his grocery shopping, since he is unable to carry the shopping bags.  He struggles to get by with 
4  his monthly $336 in General Assistance benefits and $189 in food stamps.  He often has to seek 
5  financial assistance from his brother and sister to meet basic life necessities. 
6  71.  Receiving SSI benefits would not only help Mr. Harris meet these basic needs, but 
7  it would allow him to visit his eleven year old son, who currently lives in Reno, Nevada. 
8  DISQUALIFICATION OF CONSULTATIVE EXAMINER DR. FRANK CHEN 
9  72.  Dr. Frank Chen is a medical doctor who was appointed by DDSD to be on its CE 
10  panel, and saw applicants for disability benefits in at least four different clinics, in San Francisco, 
11  Oakland, San Jose, and Pacific Grove, California. 
12  Complaints Against Dr. Frank Chen 
13  73.  Over the years, applicants and their representatives filed numerous complaints 
14  against Dr. Chen with DDSD, explaining that he had not actually conducted full physical 
15  examinations as he stated in his reports.  His examinations were not based on medically 
16  acceptable clinical diagnostic techniques, and sometimes included unauthorized neurological 
17  examinations.  Dr. Chen’s reports ignored diagnoses, findings, and symptoms described in his 
18  patients’ medical records, which he claimed to have reviewed.  His reports were internally 
19  inconsistent.  Applicants also complained that Dr. Chen acted unprofessionally and displayed a 
20  lack of attention and concern during their brief appointments.  He interrupted applicants when 
21  they tried to describe their diagnoses and symptoms and laughed when they described the list of 
22  medications they were taking.  He made inappropriate comments about religion and about 
23  patients’ personal characteristics.  When applicants described certain conditions, Dr. Chen 
24  responded that they should go “tell the mental examiner” or “save it for the mental doctor.” 
25  Corrective Action Letters to Dr. Frank Chen 
26  74.  On September 2, 2011, DDSD sent Dr. Chen an initial Corrective Action letter 
27  identifying four areas of concern: the quality of his CE reports, the lack of thoroughness of his 
28 
CLASS ACTION COMPLAINT  12 
 
 

Case 3:15-cv-00623-JST   Document 1   Filed 02/09/15   Page 15 of 26
1  examinations, religious comments made during examinations, and conducting unauthorized 
2  neurological examinations. 
3  75.  DDSD sent a second Corrective Action letter to Dr. Chen on October 14, 2013, 
4  identifying continuing problems with the quality of his CE reports, the lack of thoroughness of his 
5  examinations, and his unprofessional manner towards applicants. 
6  Removal from CE Panel 
7  76.  Finding Dr. Chen had not made the changes required to provide adequate service 
8  and continuing to receive complaints about Dr. Chen, the DDSD removed Dr. Chen from the CE 
9  panel as of December 30, 2013 due to Dr. Chen’s “unprofessional manner and failure to 
10  adequately correct deficiencies in his CE reports.” 
11  77.  Plaintiffs and members of the class were given no notice of Dr. Chen’s 
12  disqualification.   
13  78.  Even after his disqualification, Dr. Chen’s reports have still been treated as 
14  competent evidence by the Social Security Administration.  His reports continue to be relied upon 
15  by the Office of Disability Adjudication and Review (ODAR) and courts making determinations 
16  of eligibility for benefits. 
17  LEGAL FRAMEWORK 
18  79.  The Social Security Act requires the SSA to provide benefits to qualified 
19  individuals with disabilities who are “unable to engage in any substantial gainful activity by 
20  reason of any medically determinable physical or mental impairment which can be expected to 
21  result in death or which has lasted or can be expected to last for a continuous period of not less 
22  than twelve months.”  42 U.S.C. §§ 423(d)(1)(A), 1382c(a)(3)(A). 
23  80.  While the SSA administers these benefit programs, it contracts with state agencies 
24  to make the disability determinations under standards established by SSA.  20 C.F.R.                   
25  § 404.1503(a).  In California, these disability determinations are made by the DDSD. 
26  Standards for Medical Evidence 
27  81.  The existence of an individual’s disabling impairment must be supported by 
28  medical evidence: “there must be medical signs and findings, established by medically acceptable 
CLASS ACTION COMPLAINT  13 
 
 

Case 3:15-cv-00623-JST   Document 1   Filed 02/09/15   Page 16 of 26
1  clinical or laboratory diagnostic techniques[.]”   42 U.S.C. § 423(d)(5)(A); see also 42 U.S.C. 
2  § 1382c(a)(3)(D). 
3  82.  Defendant is responsible for establishing uniform standards to be applied at all 
4  levels of disability determinations.  42 U.S.C. § 421(k)(1).  The determination that an individual 
5  is disabled must be based on “evidence from acceptable medical sources” to establish whether an 
6  individual has a medically determinable impairment.  20 C.F.R. §§ 404.1513(a), 416.913(a). 
7  83.  If the evidence provided by the claimant’s own medical sources is inadequate to 
8  determine if he or she is disabled, additional medical information may be sought by contacting 
9  claimant’s sources or by arranging for a consultative examination. 
10  84.  Defendant violated its mandate under the SSA and its implementing regulations to 
11  use evidence from acceptable medical sources by relying upon deficient CE reports from 
12  Dr. Chen in denying or terminating SSI and SSDI benefits. 
13  Consultative Examinations and Reports 
14  85.  CEs are one-time physical or mental examinations performed by medical doctors 
15  and other health professionals who are contractors with the DDSD.   
16  86.  The SSA’s internal operating instructions—known as the Program Operations 
17  Manual System (“POMS”)—list specific tests which should be performed for different types of 
18  exams.  POMS Disability Insurance (DI) 22510.021 et seq., available at 
19  https://secure.ssa.gov/apps10/poms.nsf/partlist.  The POMS provisions also list minimum 
20  scheduling intervals for different types of exams to “[a]llow sufficient time to permit the medical 
21  source to take a case history and perform the examination, including any needed tests.”  Id. at DI 
22  39545.250.  For example, the minimum scheduling interval for a comprehensive general medical 
23  examination is “at least 30 minutes.”  Id. 
24  87.  Following the CE, the examiner submits a CE report to the DDSD. 
25  88.  The SSA has promulgated specific guidelines regarding the content of these CE 
26  reports.  Consultative Examinations: A Guide for Health Professionals Part III, available at 
27  http://www.ssa.gov/disability/professionals/greenbook/ce-guidelines.htm.  The guidelines direct a 
28  CE to use “standard reporting principles for a complete medical examination,” including detailed 
CLASS ACTION COMPLAINT  14 
 
 

Case 3:15-cv-00623-JST   Document 1   Filed 02/09/15   Page 17 of 26
1  reporting of the applicant’s medical history, the results of the physical examination, any 
2  laboratory findings, and discussion of conclusions.  Id. 
3  89.  The guidelines also state that the CE report “should be complete enough to enable 
4  an independent reviewer to determine the nature, severity and duration of the claimant’s 
5  impairment,” as well as “the claimant’s ability to perform basic work-related functions.”  Id.  The 
6  physician must provide a narrative of the applicant’s medical history and the physical 
7  examination.  Id. 
8  90.  The guidelines require that conclusions in the CE report must be consistent with 
9  “all available information,” including the “objective clinical findings found on examination and 
10  the claimant’s symptoms” and medical history.  Id.  For adults, the CE report “should include a 
11  description, based on the [CE’s] own findings, of the individual’s ability to do basic work-related 
12  activities.  It should not include an opinion as to whether the claimant is disabled under the 
13  meaning of the law.”  Id. 
14  91.  The guidelines explicitly outline seven requirements for a CE report.  It must: 
15  Provide evidence that serves as an adequate basis for disability 
decision-making in terms of the impairment it assesses. 
16 
Be internally consistent, and ensure that all the diseases, 
17  impairments and complaints described in the history are adequately 
assessed and reported in the clinical findings. 
18 
Correlate conclusions with the medical history, the clinical 
19  examination and laboratory tests, and explain all abnormalities. 
20  Be consistent with the other information available within the 
specialty of the examination requested. 
21 
Mention important or relevant complaints within the consultative 
22  examiner’s specialty that is noted in other evidence in the file (e.g., 
blindness in one eye, amputations, pain, alcoholism, depression). 
23 
Be adequate as compared to the standards set out in the course of a 
24  medical education. 
25  Be properly signed. 
26  Id. 
27  92.  The DDSD then relies on the CE report in making its disability recommendation.  
28  20 C.F.R. §§ 404.1517 – 404.1519t, §§ 416.917 – 416.919t. 
CLASS ACTION COMPLAINT  15 
 
 

Case 3:15-cv-00623-JST   Document 1   Filed 02/09/15   Page 18 of 26
1  93.  Because a CE report is used in making disability determinations, SSA regulations 
2  require that it be evidence from an “acceptable medical source[].”  20 C.F.R. §§ 404.1513(a), 
3  416.913(a). 
4  94.  Defendant’s reliance upon deficient CE reports from Dr. Chen in denying or 
5  terminating SSI and SSDI benefits is contrary to these guidelines. 
6  Monitoring of Consultative Examinations and Examiners 
7  95.  The Social Security Act tasks the Commissioner of Social Security to proscribe 
8  regulations through which the consultative examination process and its examiners are monitored.  
9  42 U.S.C. § 421(j)(3) (“The Commissioner of Social Security shall prescribe regulations which 
10  set forth . . . procedures by which the Commissioner of Social Security will monitor . . . the 
11  product of professionals to whom cases are referred.”). 
12  96.  Defendant is responsible for monitoring and ensuring the adequacy of the CE 
13  process, including providers.  See 20 C.F.R. §§ 404.1519s(g), 416.919s(g) (“The State agencies 
14  will cooperate with us when we conduct monitoring activities in connection with their oversight 
15  management of their consultative examination programs.”). 
16  97.  The SSA’s policy and practice of relying upon CE reports performed by Dr. Chen 
17  is contrary to Defendant’s duty to monitor and ensure the adequacy of the CE process and 
18  providers. 
19  Disqualified Consultative Examiners 
20  98.  The SSA may disqualify a medical provider from performing CEs on its behalf.  
21  Social Security Hearings, Appeals, and Litigation Law Manual (“HALLEX”) Ch. I-2-1-32, 
22  available at http://ssa.gov/OP_Home/hallex/hallex.html. 
23  99.  Even after an examiner has been disqualified, Defendant may still rely on existing 
24  reports from that examiner as “existing medical evidence.”  See 20 C.F.R. §§ 404.1503a, 
25  416.903a (“We will not use in our program any individual or entity, except to provide existing 
26  medical evidence, who is currently excluded, suspended, or otherwise barred[.]”) (emphasis 
27  added).  But to the extent that Defendant relies on those existing reports—where those reports are 
28  deficient and the CE has been disqualified, at least in part, because of such deficiency—to 
CLASS ACTION COMPLAINT  16 
 
 

Case 3:15-cv-00623-JST   Document 1   Filed 02/09/15   Page 19 of 26
1  determine an individual’s disability, such policy and practice violates Defendant’s obligation to 
2  use evidence from acceptable medical sources.  20 C.F.R. §§ 404.1513(a), 416.913(a). 
3  100.  There is no rule or regulation directing SSA employees to provide applicants 
4  whose benefits have been denied or terminated any notice that their examiner has been 
5  disqualified.  According to “HALLEX”—the Hearings, Appeals, and Litigation Law Manual that 
6  provides policies and guidance for processing and adjudicating disability claims—the SSA leaves 
7  it to the state agency to decide whether they should provide notice to the Office of Disability 
8  Adjudication and Review.  HALLEX Ch. I-2-1-32(A) (DDS “may provide formal notice” to the 
9  ODAR of a disqualification and “[i]n most circumstances, DDS will identify cases pending in 
10  ODAR that require further action because the record contains a consultative examination 
11  performed by the disqualified consultative examiner.”) (emphasis added). 
12  101.  Moreover, any review of a denial or termination of benefits is done on an 
13  individual basis: an ALJ “must evaluate the allegation of disqualification” based only “on the 
14  medical evidence of record” for that claimant, and issue a decision after weighing that evidence.  
15  Id. I-2-1-32(B).  The ALJ “will not rely on or associate evidence of a consultative examiner 
16  disqualification submitted by one claimant with a different claimant’s file.”  Id. 
17  Review of Disability Determinations 
18  102.  The Commissioner of Social Security has the authority to review any disability 
19  determination, either before or after any action is taken to implement the disability determination.  
20  42 U.S.C. § 421(c)(1). 
21  103.  SSA has promulgated regulations dictating the circumstances under which an 
22  applicant’s disability determination or decision may be reopened for both the SSDI and SSI 
23  programs.  For the SSDI program, 20 C.F.R. § 404.988 states: 
24  A determination, revised determination, decision, or revised 
decision may be reopened— 
25 
(a) Within 12 months of the date of the notice of the initial 
26  determination, for any reason; 
27  (b) Within four years of the date of the notice of the initial 
determination if we find good cause, as defined in § 404.989, to 
28  reopen the case; or 
CLASS ACTION COMPLAINT  17 
 
 

Case 3:15-cv-00623-JST   Document 1   Filed 02/09/15   Page 20 of 26
(c) At any time if— 
1 
(1) It was obtained by fraud or similar fault (see § 416.1488(c) 
2  of this chapter for factors which we take into account in 
determining fraud or similar fault)[.] 
3   
4 
104.  For the SSI program, 20 C.F.R. § 416.1488 states: 
5 
A determination, revised determination, decision, or revised 
6  decision may be reopened— 
7  (a) Within 12 months of the date of the notice of the initial 
determination, for any reason; 
8 
(b) Within two years of the date of the notice of the initial 
9  determination if we find good cause, as defined in § 416.1489, to 
reopen the case; or 
10 
(c) At any time if it was obtained by fraud or similar fault.  In 
11  determining whether a determination or decision was obtained by 
fraud or similar fault, we will take into account any physical, 
12  mental, educational, or linguistic limitations (including any lack of 
facility with the English language) which you may have had at the 
13  time.   
 
14 
105.  “Good cause” for reopening a determination or decision will be found if: 
15 
(1) New and material evidence is furnished; 
16 
(2) A clerical error in the computation or recomputation of benefits 
17  was made; or 
18  (3) The evidence that was considered in making the determination 
or decision clearly shows on its face that an error was made.  
19   
20  20 C.F.R. §§ 404.989, 416.1489. 
21  106.  “Fraud” exists “when a person, with intent to defraud, either: (1) Makes or causes 
22  to be made a false statement or misrepresentation of a material fact for use in determining rights 
23  to Social Security benefits; or (2) Conceals or fails to disclose a material fact for use in 
24  determining rights to Social Security benefits.”  POMS General (GN) § 04020.010(A)(1). 
25  107.  “Similar fault” exists “when a person either: (1) Knowingly makes an incorrect or 
26  incomplete statement that is material to the determination; or (2) Knowingly conceals information 
27  that is material to the determination.  However, fraudulent intent is not required.”  Id. GN              
28  § 04020.010(A)(2). 
CLASS ACTION COMPLAINT  18 
 
 

Case 3:15-cv-00623-JST   Document 1   Filed 02/09/15   Page 21 of 26
1  CLASS ACTION ALLEGATIONS 
2  108.  Plaintiffs bring this action as a class action pursuant to Rule 23(b)(2) of the 
3  Federal Rules of Civil Procedure. 
4  109.  This class consists of: 
5  All persons whose SSI disability or SSDI benefits were either 
denied or terminated and for whom a consultative examination 
6  report was prepared by Dr. Frank Chen.  
7  110.  The class is so numerous that joinder of all members is impracticable. While the 
8  exact number of class members can only be obtained through appropriate discovery, on 
9  information and belief, there are hundreds and possibly thousands of class members whose SSI 
10  and/or SSDI benefits were either denied or terminated because of reliance upon, in whole or in 
11  part, a consultative examination report from Dr. Chen.   
12  111.  There are questions of law and fact common to all class members that predominate 
13  over questions only affecting individual class members. Such questions include, among others:  
14  a.  Whether Defendant violated its mandate under the SSA and its implementing 
15  regulations to use evidence from acceptable medical sources by relying upon 
16  deficient CE reports from Dr. Chen in denying or terminating SSI and SSDI 
17  benefits. 
18  b.  Whether Defendant violated its obligation under the SSA and its implementing 
19  regulations to monitor and ensure the adequacy of the consultative examination 
20  process and providers by relying upon deficient CE reports from Dr. Chen in 
21  denying or terminating SSI and SSDI benefits. 
22  c.  Whether Plaintiffs and members of the class were deprived of due process by 
23  Defendant’s failure to provide them with a complete and thorough consultative 
24  examination by a competent consultative examiner, in violation of the Fifth 
25  Amendment of the U.S. Constitution. 
26  d.  Whether Plaintiffs and members of the class were deprived of due process by 
27  Defendant’s failure to notify them of the disqualification of Dr. Chen, in violation 
28  of the Fifth Amendment of the U.S. Constitution. 
CLASS ACTION COMPLAINT  19 
 
 

Case 3:15-cv-00623-JST   Document 1   Filed 02/09/15   Page 22 of 26
1  e.  Whether Plaintiffs and members of the class were deprived of due process by 
2  Defendant’s failure to provide them with copies of their consultative examination 
3  report, in violation of the Fifth Amendment of the U.S. Constitution.  
4  f.  Whether, under the Social Security Act and regulations, Plaintiffs and members of 
5  the class are entitled to have their claims reopened and redetermined on the basis 
6  of “good cause” because new and material evidence has been furnished as to the 
7  adequacy of their CE examinations and reports from Dr. Chen. 
8  g.  Whether, under the Social Security Act and regulations, Plaintiffs and members of 
9  the class are entitled to have their claims reopened and redetermined on the basis 
10  of “good cause” because those determinations relied on a defective CE report from 
11  Dr. Chen that clearly shows on its face that error(s) were made. 
12  h.  Whether, under the Social Security Act and regulations, Plaintiffs and members of 
13  the class are entitled to have their claims reopened and redetermined on the basis 
14  of “fraud or similar fault” because Dr. Chen knew he was making incorrect or 
15  incomplete statements in his CE reports. 
16  i.  Whether, under the Social Security Act and regulations, Plaintiffs and members of 
17  the class are entitled to have their claims reopened and redetermined on the basis 
18  of “fraud or similar fault” because Dr. Chen knowingly concealed material 
19  information when he prepared his CE reports. 
20  j.  Whether, under the Social Security Act and regulations, Plaintiffs and members of 
21  the class are entitled to a new CE report from an acceptable medical source. 
22  k.  Whether, under the Social Security Act and regulations, Plaintiffs and members of 
23  the class are entitled to have their claims reopened and redetermined without any 
24  reliance on Dr. Chen’s consultative examination and report. 
25  112.  Plaintiffs’ claims are typical of the claims of all class members, and arise from the 
26  same need to have their applications reopened and redetermined without any reliance on 
27  Dr. Chen’s consultative examination reports.  The declaratory and injunctive relief sought is 
28  common to all class members. 
CLASS ACTION COMPLAINT  20 
 
 

Case 3:15-cv-00623-JST   Document 1   Filed 02/09/15   Page 23 of 26
1  113.  A class action is superior to other available methods for a fair and efficient 
2  adjudication of this matter in that the prosecution of separate actions by individual class members 
3  would unduly burden the Court and create the possibility of conflicting decisions. 
4  114.  Plaintiffs will fairly and adequately protect the interests of the class members. 
5  115.  The named plaintiffs and the proposed class are represented by National Senior 
6  Citizens Law Center, Morrison & Foerster LLP, and Legal Aid Society of San Mateo County, 
7  whose attorneys are experienced in class action litigation and will adequately represent the class. 
8  116.  Defendant has acted on grounds generally applicable to the class, by relying on 
9  defective CEs from Dr. Chen, that failed to meet the mandates in the SSA and its implementing 
10  regulations to use evidence from acceptable medical sources to establish whether an individual 
11  has a medically determinable impairment and to monitor and ensure the adequacy of the CE 
12  process and providers. 
13  117.  If class certification is not granted, individuals would be forced to bring separate 
14  actions, thereby wasting judicial resources, as well as the time of attorneys from government 
15  agencies and legal services providers. 
16  FIRST CAUSE OF ACTION 
17  FOR DECLARATORY AND INJUNCTIVE RELIEF FOR 
Improper Reliance on Dr. Frank Chen CE Reports 
18   
19  118.  Paragraphs 1 – 117 are each re-alleged and incorporated as if fully set forth herein. 
20  119.  The Social Security Act and the regulations promulgated thereunder, 42 U.S.C. 
21  §§ 421, 423 and 1383b, 20 C.F.R. §§ 404.1512 – 404.1513 and 416.912 – 416.913, require 
22  Defendant to base disability determinations on evidence from acceptable medical sources.   
23  120.  The SSA’s policy and practice of relying upon CE reports performed by Dr. Chen 
24  violates Defendant’s legal obligation to base disability determinations on evidence from 
25  acceptable medical sources.   
26  121.  This policy and practice violates the Social Security Act and its implementing 
27  regulations. 
28 
CLASS ACTION COMPLAINT  21 
 
 

Case 3:15-cv-00623-JST   Document 1   Filed 02/09/15   Page 24 of 26
1  122.  Defendant has the authority to review the disability determinations of Plaintiffs 
2  and class members.  42 U.S.C. § 421(c)(1). 
3  123.  Pursuant to the 20 C.F.R. §§ 404.988, 404.989, 416.1488, 416.1489, grounds exist 
4  to reopen these determinations. 
5  SECOND CAUSE OF ACTION 
6  FOR DECLARATORY AND INJUNCTIVE RELIEF FOR 
Improper Reliance on Dr. Frank Chen CE Reports 
7   
8  124.  Paragraphs 1 – 123 are each re-alleged and incorporated as if fully set forth herein. 
9  125.  The Social Security Act tasks the Commissioner of Social Security to proscribe 
10  regulations through which the consultative examination process and its examiners are monitored.  
11  42 U.S.C. § 421(j)(3). 
12  126.  SSA regulations assign Defendant responsibility for monitoring and ensuring the 
13  adequacy of the CE process and providers.  20 C.F.R. §§ 404.1519s(g), 416.919s(g). 
14  127.  Accordingly, the SSA’s policy and practice of relying upon CE reports performed 
15  by Dr. Chen is irreconcilable with Defendant’s duty to monitor and ensure the adequacy of the 
16  CE process and providers. 
17  128.  This policy and practice violates the Social Security Act and its implementing 
18  regulations. 
19  129.  Defendant has the authority to review the disability determinations of Plaintiffs 
20  and class members.  42 U.S.C. § 421(c)(1). 
21  130.  Pursuant to the 20 C.F.R. §§ 404.988, 404.989, 416.1488, 416.1489, grounds exist 
22  to reopen these determinations. 
23  THIRD CAUSE OF ACTION 
FOR DECLARATORY AND INJUNCTIVE RELIEF FOR 
24 
Violation of the Fifth Amendment of the United States Constitution, 
 Actionable Pursuant to 42 U.S.C. § 1983 (Due Process) 
25 
26 
131.  Paragraphs 1 – 130 are each re-alleged and incorporated as if fully set forth herein. 
27 
28 
CLASS ACTION COMPLAINT  22 
 
 

Case 3:15-cv-00623-JST   Document 1   Filed 02/09/15   Page 25 of 26
1  132.  Defendant’s failure to provide Plaintiffs and class members with a complete and 
2  thorough consultative examination by a competent consultative examiner violates Plaintiffs’ and 
3  class members’ Fifth Amendment rights to procedural due process. 
4  133.  Defendant’s failure to notify Plaintiffs and class members of the disqualification of 
5  Dr. Chen violates Plaintiffs’ and class members’ Fifth Amendment rights to procedural due 
6  process. 
7  134.  Defendant’s failure to provide Plaintiffs and class members with copies of their 
8  CE report violates Plaintiffs’ and class members’ Fifth Amendment rights to procedural due 
9  process.   
10  135.  As a result, Plaintiffs and members of the class were denied an opportunity for a 
11  fair and adequate notice and hearing.  
12  PRAYER FOR RELIEF 
13  WHEREFORE Plaintiffs respectfully request that the Court: 
14  a.  Assume jurisdiction over this matter; 
15  b.  Certify this action as a class action pursuant to Rule 23(b)(2) of the Federal Rules 
16  of Civil Procedure; 
17  c.  Declare that Defendant’s policies and practices, as set forth above, violate the 
18  SSA’s obligations pursuant to the Social Security Act, its implementing 
19  regulations and the Due Process Clause of the United States Constitution; 
20  d.  Preliminarily and permanently enjoin Defendant from relying on consultative 
21  exam reports from Dr. Frank Chen to terminate or deny SSI and/or SSDI benefits; 
22  e.  Preliminarily and permanently enjoin Defendant to reopen all prior determinations 
23  terminating or denying SSI and/or SSDI benefits that relied, in whole or in part, on 
24  a consultative exam report from Dr. Frank Chen, and to offer Plaintiffs the 
25  opportunity for a new consultative examination from a well-qualified clinician;  
26  f.  Preliminarily and permanently enjoin Defendant to provide notice to individuals 
27  whose claims for SSI and/or SSDI benefits were terminated or denied, in whole or 
28  in part, on a consultative exam report from Dr. Frank Chen;  
CLASS ACTION COMPLAINT  23 
 
 

Case 3:15-cv-00623-JST   Document 1   Filed 02/09/15   Page 26 of 26
1  g.  Award Plaintiffs costs, disbursements, and reasonable attorneys’ fees, including, 
2  without limitation, the costs and fees authorized by 28 U.S.C. § 2412; 
3  h.  Grant Plaintiffs such other and further relief as the Court may find just, proper and 
4  equitable. 
 
5

1  NOTICE OF MOTION AND MOTION FOR CLASS CERTIFICATION 
2  PLEASE TAKE NOTICE that on October 8, 2015, at 2:00p.m., or as soon thereafter as 
3  the matter may be heard, in Courtroom 9, 19th Floor of the United States District Courthouse, 
4  450 Golden Gate Avenue, San Francisco, California 94102, before the Honorable Jon S. Tigar, 
5  Plaintiffs Kevin Hart, Nina Silva-Collins, and Lee Harris, on behalf of themselves and all others 
6  similarly situated (“Plaintiffs”), will, and hereby do, move the Court for an Order certifying the 
7  above-captioned action to proceed as a class action and appointing Plaintiffs’ counsel as class 
8  counsel. 
9  This Motion is made pursuant to Federal Civil Procedure Rule 23 on the grounds that this 
10  matter meets all the requirements for class certification set forth in Rule 23.  The Motion is based 
11  upon this Notice; the accompanying Memorandum of Points and Authorities; the Declarations of 
12  Trinh Phan, Kyle Kitson, Nyla Moujaes, Anna Rich, William Stern, and Andy Chu in Support of 
13  Plaintiffs’ Motion for Class Certification, filed concurrently herewith; the pleadings and all 
14  documents on file in this action; and such other matters as may be presented at or before the 
15  hearing. 
16  Plaintiffs request that this Court grant Plaintiffs’ motion, certify this matter as a class 
17  action, and appoint Plaintiffs’ counsel as class counsel. 
18   
 
19  Dated: August 6, 2015  WILLIAM L. STERN 
  CLAUDIA M. VETESI 
20  ROBERT T. PETRAGLIA 
ELIZABETH BALASSONE 
21  MORRISON & FOERSTER LLP 
22

WILLIAM L. STERN

PLAINTIFFS’ MOTION FOR CLASS CERTIFICATION  v 
CASE NO. 3:15-CV-00623-JST 
sf-3554959  
 

Case 3:15-cv-00623-JST   Document 40   Filed 08/06/15   Page 8 of 28
 
1  I.  INTRODUCTION 
2  This is a class action for declaratory and injunctive relief only, in which Plaintiffs seek 
3  class certification under Rule 23(b)(2).  Only three facts matter for purposes of this motion, and 
4  all are uncontested.   
5  First, after repeated complaints, the Social Security Administration (SSA) disqualified 
6  Dr. Frank Chen in December 2013 from performing further consultative examinations (“CE”) due 
7  to deficiencies in his reports and the inadequacy of his examinations.  Second, before he was 
8  disqualified, Dr. Chen submitted CE reports in at least 325 cases that resulted in a denial of 
9  benefits and are now pending at the hearing level.  That is only the tip of the iceberg, because it 
10  does not include cases where an applicant may have simply dropped his or her claim after it was 
11  denied, and does not include cases still at the pre-hearing stage.  Altogether, the class likely 
12  consists of thousands of claimants.  Third, the SSA has now admitted—through an attempted 
13  partial fix after this lawsuit was filed—that the integrity of the administrative process was 
14  compromised by Dr. Chen’s CE reports.  Yet, the SSA has instructed its adjudicators that these 
15  reports may be considered nonetheless.  
16  This is bad enough for those 325 claimants, because Dr. Chen’s reports could still play a 
17  role in a denial or termination of their claims.  But claimants do not ordinarily get to see the CE 
18  reports, so what about the many claimants who never even saw theirs?  They were never told that 
19  their denials or terminations were based on an unreliable report from Dr. Chen.  They likely 
20  would not have had any reason to know they had grounds to challenge the SSA’s determination, 
21  let alone possess the resources to pursue those claims even if they knew they had been wronged.  
22  For them, the SSA’s attempted fix in the course of litigation is empty, and too late.   
23  Every SSA claimant is entitled to a fair process.  Whether any given claimant is ultimately 
24  found to be entitled to Supplemental Security Income (SSI) or Social Security Disability 
25  Insurance (SSDI) benefits is not at issue.  This Court is not being asked to decide that.  Here, 
26  every class member’s process was tainted by a common injury, the SSA’s policy of considering 
27  CE reports prepared by Dr. Chen in resolving their disability claims. 
28 
PLAINTIFFS’ MOTION FOR CLASS CERTIFICATION  1 
CASE NO. 3:15-CV-00623-JST 
sf-3554959  
 

Case 3:15-cv-00623-JST   Document 40   Filed 08/06/15   Page 9 of 28
 
1  That this was a policy cannot be disputed.  In its motion to dismiss, SSA argued that there 
2  was no “policy” being challenged, hence, each aggrieved claimant must individually run the 
3  procedural gauntlet, one by one, and exhaust his or her administrative remedy.  But this Court 
4  concluded that exhaustion would be futile.  It found that SSA’s use of reports by Dr. Chen was a 
5  “policy.”  That finding establishes the commonality element of Rule 23(a), because each class 
6  member was aggrieved by a policy this Court described as “an SSA-wide policy to consider 
7  Dr. Chen’s reports in resolving disability claims, even in the wake of widespread allegations of 
8  deficiencies in the quality of his examinations.” 
9  There is nothing novel about what Plaintiffs seek.  In fact, it is precisely the kind of relief 
10  ordered by the district court in Bowen v. City of New York upon certification of a class of 
11  individuals who had been denied disability benefits or whose benefits had been terminated 
12  pursuant to an allegedly unlawful policy: reopen decisions denying or terminating benefits, and 
13  notify class members that their claims had been reopened.  476 U.S. 467, 475-76 & n.7 (1986). 
14  The Court should certify the proposed class, and allow Named Plaintiffs to seek relief on 
15  behalf of all those who had a CE report from Dr. Chen and were denied benefits or had their 
16  benefits terminated. 
17  II.  ISSUE TO BE DECIDED 
18  The issue to be decided is whether Plaintiffs’ claims satisfy the requirements for class 
19  certification under Federal Rules of Civil Procedure 23(a) and 23(b)(2). 
20  III.  BACKGROUND 
21  A.  SSA Is Obliged to Provide a Fair Process for Determining Whether 
Claimants Are Entitled to Benefits.   
22   
23  To obtain benefits based on disability under the SSI or SSDI programs, a claimant must be 
24  unable “to engage in any substantial gainful activity by reason of any medically determinable 
25  physical or mental impairment which can be expected to result in death or which has lasted or can 
26  be expected to last for a continuous period of not less than 12 months.”  42 U.S.C. 
27  § 423(d)(1)(A).  A claimant must provide SSA with “evidence from acceptable medical sources to 
28  establish whether [the individual has] a medically determinable impairment[].”  20 C.F.R. 
PLAINTIFFS’ MOTION FOR CLASS CERTIFICATION  2 
CASE NO. 3:15-CV-00623-JST 
sf-3554959  
 

Case 3:15-cv-00623-JST   Document 40   Filed 08/06/15   Page 10 of 28
 
1  § 404.1513(a).  SSA administers these benefit programs, but contracts with state agencies, such as 
2  California’s Disability Determination Service Division (DDSD) of the Department of Social 
3  Services, to make the disability determinations under standards established by SSA.  Id. 
4  § 404.1503(a). 
5  If the DDSD finds that an applicant’s own medical records are insufficient to render a 
6  decision, it can refer the applicant to a contracting doctor for a CE.   Id. §§ 404.1519, 416.919.  
7  The doctor performing a CE must be licensed, have adequate training, experience, and equipment 
8  to perform the CE, and not otherwise be barred from participating in SSA programs.  Id.  
9  §§ 404.1519g, 416.919g. 
10  Federal law provides the standard for determining whether someone is disabled:  “there 
11  must be medical signs and findings, established by medically acceptable clinical or laboratory 
12  diagnostic techniques.”   42 U.S.C. § 423(d)(5)(A) (emphasis added); see also id. 
13  § 1382c(a)(3)(D).  SSA bears the ultimate responsibility to establish “uniform standards which 
14  shall be applied at all levels of determination, review, and adjudication in determining whether 
15  individuals are under disabilities.”  Id. § 421(k)(1).  SSA regulations require that the 
16  determination that an individual is disabled be based on “evidence from acceptable medical 
17  sources.”  20 C.F.R. §§ 404.1513(a), 416.913(a).   
18  Further, the Commissioner of Social Security is charged with prescribing procedures for 
19  monitoring both the CE referral processes used, and the product of doctors to whom cases are 
20  referred for CEs.  42 U.S.C. § 421(j)(3).  The resulting regulations explain SSA’s responsibility 
21  for monitoring and ensuring the adequacy of the CE process, including providers.  See 20 C.F.R. 
22  § 416.919t; see also id. § 416.919j (SSA will review allegations that a medical source designated 
23  to perform a CE “lacks objectivity.”); id. § 416.919s(g) (“The State agencies will cooperate with 
24  [SSA] when [it] conduct[s] monitoring activities in connection with their oversight management 
25  of their consultative examination programs.”).  
26  Upon submission of a claim for benefits, the applicant first receives an initial 
27  determination of his or her claim.   Id. §§ 404.902, 416.1402.  If the applicant is denied, he or she 
28  may seek reconsideration.  Id. §§ 404.929, 416.1429.  If the claim is once again denied, then the 
PLAINTIFFS’ MOTION FOR CLASS CERTIFICATION  3 
CASE NO. 3:15-CV-00623-JST 
sf-3554959  
 

Case 3:15-cv-00623-JST   Document 40   Filed 08/06/15   Page 11 of 28
 
1  applicant must, within sixty days, request a hearing before an Administrative Law Judge (“ALJ”).  
2  Id. §§ 404.930, 404.933, 416.1430, 416.1433.  If the applicant does not pursue a hearing, the 
3  initial denial becomes binding.  Id. §§ 404.921, 416.1421.  If the claimant requests a hearing, an 
4  ALJ is assigned to the case, and required to review all evidence in the record.  Id. §§ 404.929, 
5  416.1429.  The ALJ will then conduct a hearing and issue a written decision.  Id. §§ 404.944, 
6  404.953, 416.1444, 416.1453.  If the applicant is denied again, he or she has sixty days to request 
7  review from the Appeals Council.  Id. §§ 404.967-68, 416.1467-416.1468.  The Appeals Council 
8  will grant review if there has been an abuse of discretion or an error of law, or if the ALJ’s 
9  actions, findings, or conclusions are not supported by substantial evidence in the record.  Id. 
10  §§ 404.970(a), 416.1470(a).  The Appeals Council may decline to review the case, or remand it to 
11  an ALJ, or render a decision.  Id. §§ 404.967, 416.1467.  If the Appeals Council chooses not to 
12  review the case, then the ALJ’s decision becomes binding.  Id. §§ 404.955, 416.1455.  If the 
13  Appeals Council refuses to review the case, or issues an adverse decision, the applicant must then 
14  file a complaint in federal court. 
15  B.  SSA Denied Plaintiffs and Proposed Class Members a Fair Process. 
16  Plaintiffs and proposed class members all received a CE report from Dr. Chen, a medical 
17  doctor who was appointed by the Disability Determination Service for the State of California to 
18  be on its CE panel.  Over the years, applicants and their representatives filed numerous 
19  complaints against Dr. Chen with DDSD, explaining that he had not actually conducted full 
20  physical examinations as he stated in his reports.  See, e.g., Declaration of Andy Chu in Supp. of 
21  Pls’ Mot. for Class Certification (“Chu Decl.”) ¶¶ 5-15, Exs. A-B.)  Dr. Chen’s reports were also 
22  internally inconsistent, and ignored diagnoses, findings, and symptoms described in the 
23  applicants’ medical records, which he claimed to have reviewed.  (See, e.g., id.)  Ultimately, 
24  Dr. Chen was disqualified because of “uncorrected deficiencies regarding the quality of his 
25  examination reports and the thoroughness of his examinations, which were the subject of 
26  corrective action letters dated September 2, 2011, and October 14, 2013.”  (Decl. of Scott J. 
27  Borrowman in Supp. of Mot. to Dismiss (“Borrowman Decl.”) Ex. B at 1, ECF No. 27-3.)   
28 
PLAINTIFFS’ MOTION FOR CLASS CERTIFICATION  4 
CASE NO. 3:15-CV-00623-JST 
sf-3554959  
 

Case 3:15-cv-00623-JST   Document 40   Filed 08/06/15   Page 12 of 28
 
1  SSA, however, never provided notice to Plaintiffs or proposed class members that 
2  Dr. Chen had been disqualified.  (See Declaration of Trinh Phan in Supp. of Pls’ Mot. for Class 
3  Certification (“Phan Decl.”) ¶ 17; Declaration of Nyla Moujaes in Supp. of Pls’ Mot. for Class 
4  Certification (“Moujaes Decl.”) ¶ 12; Declaration of Kyle Kitson in Supp. of Pls’ Mot. for Class 
5  Certification (“Kitson Decl.”) ¶ 14; see also Def.’s Answer to Class Action Compl. (“Answer”) 
6  ¶ 100, ECF No. 38 (“SSA admits that there is no regulation or rule directing SSA to provide 
7  applicants whose benefits have been denied or terminated notice that the consultative examiner in 
8  their case has been removed from the applicable CE panel.”).)  Nor did SSA reopen the 
9  applications that were tainted by Dr. Chen’s reports.  Moreover, SSA did not even inform the 
10  judges and staff who adjudicate disability claims that Dr. Chen was disqualified until over a year 
11  after his disqualification—and months after this lawsuit was filed.  (See Def.’s Reply in Supp. of 
12  Mot. to Dismiss (“Reply”) at 14:11-15:6, ECF No. 271; Borrowman Decl. Ex. B, see also id. 
13  Ex. A, ECF No. 27-2.) 
14  C.  SSA’s Post-Litigation Fix Is Inadequate. 
15  Despite the SSA’s belated admission that there were “uncorrected deficiencies regarding 
16  the quality of [Dr. Chen’s] examination reports” and questions about “the thoroughness of his 
17  examinations,” the SSA has failed to restore the integrity of the administrative process.  SSA 
18  admits that “reports from Dr. Chen generated prior to December 30, 2013 are treated as reports 
19  from acceptable medical sources under governing regulations.”  (Answer ¶ 6.)  SSA has 
20  instructed adjudicators to “consider” Dr. Chen’s removal from the panel in “determining the 
21  weight, if any, to which” Dr. Chen’s CE is entitled.  (Borrowman Decl. Ex. A at 2.)  In a 
22  March 16, 2015 memorandum to the Acting Chief Administrative Law Judge for San Francisco, 
23  the Chief Administrative Law Judge for SSA explains that Dr. Chen “was no longer authorized to 
24  perform consultative examinations (CEs) . . . premised in part on uncorrected deficiencies 
                                                 
25 
1 SSA’s own policies, which Plaintiffs claim are inadequate, place any responsibility on 
DDSD to inform adjudicators that a consultative examiner has been disqualified, and even then 
26 
qualify that DDSD “may provide formal notice to the Office of Disability Adjudication and 
Review (ODAR) through the regional consultative examination coordinator (CEC).”  Social 
27 
Security Hearings, Appeals, and Litigation Law Manual (“HALLEX”) Ch. I-2-1-32A, 
http://ssa.gov/OP_Home/hallex/hallex.html (emphasis added). 
28 
PLAINTIFFS’ MOTION FOR CLASS CERTIFICATION  5 
CASE NO. 3:15-CV-00623-JST 
sf-3554959  
 

Case 3:15-cv-00623-JST   Document 40   Filed 08/06/15   Page 13 of 28
 
1  regarding the quality of his examination reports and the thoroughness of his examinations, which 
2  were the subject of corrective action letters dated September 2, 2011, and October 14, 2013.”  (Id. 
3  at 1.) 
4  The memorandum then instructs:  “When preparing the decision, the ALJ or senior 
5  attorney advisor must consider the weight to give Dr. Chen’s report in accordance with the 
6  regulations at 20 C.F.R. 404.1527 and 416.927.”  (Id. at 2.)  These cited regulations provide that 
7  “every medical opinion” received by an ALJ will be evaluated “[r]egardless of its source[.]”  
8  20 C.F.R. §§ 404.1527(c), 416.927(c).  The regulations restrict an ALJ’s evaluation of the 
9  evidence to the face of the report, and other evidence in the record.  See id.  They do not allow an 
10  ALJ to disregard an unreliable report, or question its findings, based on the fact that the individual 
11  who prepared it has been disqualified.  See id. §§ 404.1527(b)-(c).   
12  One month later, on April 15, 2015, the Division Chief Administrative Appeals Judge

17  IV.  LEGAL STANDARDS 
18  Plaintiffs must satisfy the requirements of Federal Rule of Civil Procedure 23(a), as well 
19  as at least one of the three requirements listed in Rule 23(b).  Wal-Mart Stores, Inc. v. Dukes, 
20  131 S. Ct. 2541, 2548 (2011).  Under Rule 23(a), the party seeking certification must demonstrate 
21  that “(1) the class is so numerous that joinder of all members is impracticable; (2) there are 
22  questions of law or fact common to the class; (3) the claims or defenses of the representative 
23  parties are typical of the claims of the class; and (4) the representative parties will fairly and 
24  adequately protect the interests of the class.”  Fed. R. Civ. P. 23(a); Dukes, 131 S. Ct. at 2548.  
25  Here, Plaintiffs must also show that “the party opposing the class has acted or refused to act on 
26  grounds that apply generally to the class, so that final injunctive relief or corresponding 
27  declaratory relief is appropriate respecting the class as a whole.”  See Fed. R. Civ. P. 23(b)(2); 
28  Dukes, 131 S. Ct. at 2548-49.

14  Plaintiffs challenge the SSA-wide policy that has applied uniformly to each proposed 
15  class member: consideration of Dr. Chen’s reports in resolving disability claims.  A class bringing 
16  similar challenge to an allegedly unlawful SSA policy was certified in City of New York, 
17  including individuals who had been denied benefits or whose benefits were terminated pursuant 
18  to that policy.  476 U.S. at 475-76.  In both cases, the SSA policies provide the bases for 
19  commonality. 
20  As the Supreme Court has explained, “[c]ommonality requires the plaintiff to demonstrate 
21  that the class members ‘have suffered the same injury,’” such that “all their claims can be 
22  productively litigated at once.”  Dukes, 131 S. Ct. at 2551 (citation omitted).  The common 
23  questions must “generate common answers” that are “apt to drive the resolution of the litigation.”  
24  Id. (citation omitted).  Commonality is therefore satisfied where the claims of all class members 
25  “depend upon a common contention . . . of such a nature that it is capable of classwide 
26  resolution—which means that determination of its truth or falsity will resolve an issue that is 
27  central to the validity of each one of the claims in one stroke.”  Id.  The commonality requirement 
28  has “been construed permissively,” and “[a]ll questions of fact and law need not be common to

9  that “the claims or defenses of the representative parties [be] typical of the claims or defenses of 
10  the class.” “‘The purpose of the typicality requirement is to assure that the interest of the named 
11  representative aligns with the interests of the class.’”  Wolin v. Jaguar Land Rover N. Am., LLC, 
12  617 F.3d 1168, 1175 (9th Cir. 2010) (quoting Hanon v. Dataproducts Corp., 976 F.2d 497, 508 
13  (9th Cir. 1992)).  The typicality requirement is “‘satisfied when each class member’s claim arises 
14  from the same course of events, and each class member makes similar legal arguments to prove 
15  the defendant’s liability.’”  Rodriguez, 591 F.3d at 1124 (quoting Armstrong v. Davis, 275 F.3d 
16  849, 868 (9th Cir. 2001)).  “Like the commonality requirement, the typicality requirement is 
17  ‘permissive’ and requires only that the representative’s claims are ‘reasonably co-extensive with 
18  those of absent class members; they need not be substantially identical.’”  Rodriguez, 591 F.3d 
19  at 1124 (quoting Hanlon, 150 F.3d at 1020).

11  handling class actions, other complex litigation, and the types of claims asserted in the action; 
12  (iii) counsel’s knowledge of the applicable law; and (iv) the resources that counsel will commit to 
13  representing the class.”  Fed. R. Civ. P. 23(g)(1)(A).  Plaintiffs and proposed class members share
