tatsiD 16  I.  BACKGROUND 
S d nr
ee 17  A.  The Parties and Claims 
th
intr
Uo
N 18  This case is a putative class action against Defendant Carolyn W. Colvin, Acting 
19  Commissioner of Social Security, involving the evidence used by Administrative Law Judges 
20  (“ALJs”) in deciding whether individuals are entitled to receive disability benefits.  The evidence 
21  ALJs consider when making a disability benefits determination includes consultative evaluations 
22  (“CEs”) performed by medical professionals under the guidelines provided by the Social Security 
23  Administration (“SSA”).  SSA regulations require adjudicators to “always consider” CE reports 
24  along with the other evidence when making a disability determination.  20 C.F.R. §§ 404.1527(b), 
25  416.927(b).  The SSA contracts with state agencies, including the Disability Determination Service 
26  Division of the California Department of Social Services (DDSD) to make disability 
27  determinations.  ECF No. 36 at 2.     
28  One of the evaluators was Dr. Frank Chen.  After receiving complaints that Dr. Chen’s 

Case 3:15-cv-00623-JST   Document 88   Filed 04/17/17   Page 2 of 5
 
1  reports were of low quality, and sometimes included results of tests that he never actually 
2  performed, the DDSD disqualified him from providing CEs, citing Dr. Chen’s “unprofessional 
3  manner and failure to adequately correct deficiencies in his CE reports.”  Id. at 4.  Plaintiffs were 
4  not given notice that Dr. Chen had been disqualified, even though the SSA relied on his reports in 
5  deciding to deny their applications for disability benefits.  Plaintiffs commenced this lawsuit, 
6  asking the Court to grant declaratory and injunctive relief.  ECF No. 1 at 23-24. 
7  B.  Procedural History 
8    Plaintiffs filed their Complaint on February 9, 2015.  ECF No. 1.  After the SSA’s motion 
9  to dismiss was denied, ECF No. 36, it answered the Complaint on July 31, 2015, ECF No. 38.  
10  Plaintiffs then filed a motion for class certification, ECF No. 40, which the Court granted on 
11  October 14, 2015, ECF No. 50. 
12    Settlement negotiations began in November 2015 before Magistrate Judge Maria-Elena 
 
a
tr in
uoro 13  James.  See ECF Nos. 44-45.  On September 19, 2016, the parties reached an agreement and 
Cfi
 tla
cC 14  Plaintiffs filed an unopposed motion for preliminary approval of class action settlement 
i
rts fo
iD tc 15  agreement.  ECF No. 76.  The Court granted a motion for preliminary approval on November 9, 
 sir
et
tatsiD 16  2016, concluding that “the proposed benefits to be awarded to the class [fell] ‘within the range of 
S d nr
ee 17  possible approval,’” and that it otherwise met the criteria for approval.  ECF No. 81 at 13-14.  The 
th
intr
Uo
N 18  Court found that the settlement agreement was appropriate in light of the risk and expense of 
19  litigation, the negotiations were non-collusive, there was a government participant, and the 
20  settlement contained no obvious deficiencies or preferential treatment to any class member.  Id. at 
21  13-14.   
22  Because the class was certified under Federal Rule of Civil Procedure 23(b)(2) and the 
23  settlement provides only injunctive relief, the Court was not obliged to require the parties to 
24  provide notice of the settlement to the class.  Id. at 14-15 (citing Wal-Mart Stores, Inc. v. Duke, 
25  564 U.S. 338, 362 (2011); Green v. Am. Express Co., 200 F.R.D. 211, 212-13 (S.D.N.Y. 2001)).  
26  Nonetheless, the parties proposed and the Court ordered that notice be given, “since class 
27  members’ will have to take affirmative action if they desire their claims to be reopened, and will 
28  subsequently be notified via the claim form procedure if the settlement agreement is finally 
2 

Case 3:15-cv-00623-JST   Document 88   Filed 04/17/17   Page 3 of 5
 
1  approved.”  Id. at 15.  The Court ordered Defendant to publish a Publication Notice in newspapers 
2  of general circulation1 and Plaintiffs’ counsel to disseminate the notice to “several organizations 
3  that are likely to interact with class members.”  Id.  Individual notice was not required because 
4  “class members are not afforded an opportunity to opt out.”  Id. 
5  Plaintiffs now bring this unopposed motion for final approval of the class action settlement 
6  agreement.  ECF No. 82.   
7  II.  LEGAL STANDARD 
8  The Ninth Circuit has a “strong judicial policy” favoring the settlement of class actions. 
9  Class Plaintiffs v. City of Seattle, 955 F.2d 1268, 1276 (9th Cir. 1992).  Rule 23(e) “requires the 
10  district court to determine whether a proposed settlement is fundamentally fair, adequate, and 
11  reasonable.”  Hanlon v. Chrysler Corp., 150 F.3d 1011, 1026 (9th Cir. 1998).  The proposed 
12  settlement need not be ideal, but it must be fair and free of collusion, consistent with counsel's 
 
a
tr in
uoro 13  fiduciary obligations to the class.  Id. at 1027.  In assessing a settlement agreement, a court must 
Cfi
 tla
cC 14  weigh:  
i
rts fo
iD tc 15  [T]he strength of the plaintiffs' case; the risk, expense, complexity, and likely 
 sir
et duration of further litigation; the risk of maintaining class action status throughout 
tatsiD 16  the trial; the amount offered in settlement; the extent of discovery completed and 
S d nr the stage of the proceedings; the experience and views of counsel; the presence of a 
ee 17  governmental participant; and the reaction of the class members to the proposed 
th
intr settlement. 
Uo
N 18 
Id. at 1026.  The court need not consider all of these factors, and may consider others.  In re 
19 
Bluetooth Headset Prods. Liab. Litig., 654 F.3d 935, 942 (9th Cir. 2011).   
20 
III.  DISCUSSION 
21 
A.  Notice Publication 
22 
When a class is certified under Rule 23(b), courts typically do not require the parties to 
23 
notify the class.  Jamba Juice Co., 2015 WL 1248027, at *8.  Moreover, when a settlement 
24 
25 
                                                 
26  1 In its preliminary approval of the settlement agreement, the Court initially ordered that the notice 
be published in three newspapers of general circulation.  ECF No. 81 at 15.  On November 8, 
27  2016, the Defendant filed an unopposed Amendment to the Settlement agreement, specifying five 
newspapers in which the SSA would publish the notice: San Francisco Chronicle, San Francisco 
28 
Examiner, San Luis Obispo Tribune, Monterey Herald, and Santa Cruz Sentinel.  ECF No. 79 at 3. 
3 

Case 3:15-cv-00623-JST   Document 88   Filed 04/17/17   Page 4 of 5
 
1  provides only injunctive relief, as is the case here, notice “is not uniformly required.”  Green v. 
2  Am. Express Co., 200 F.R.D. 211, 212-13 (S.D.N.Y. 2001).  In its preliminary approval of the 
3  settlement agreement, however, the Court found that publication of notice would nonetheless be 
4  wise, and ordered notice to be published in newspapers of general circulation and organizations 
5  likely to come in contact with class members.  ECF No. 81 at 15.   
6  The parties have complied with the publication requirement.  Defendant published notice 
7  of the settlement in five newspapers and Plaintiffs’ counsel disseminated the notice to a number of 
8  organizations’ publications within the time limits established by the Court.  See ECF No. 82-1 
9  (Decl. of Trinh Phan), 82-2 (Decl. of Patricia Raymond).  The Court finds that the class notice 
10  plan was implemented properly.  
11  B.  Fairness, Adequacy, and Reasonableness of the Settlement 
12  The Court previously found that the settlement agreement fell within the range of possible 
 
a
tr in
uoro 13  approval, with no obvious deficiencies, no preferential treatment to any class member, and 
Cfi
 tla
cC 14  resulting from non-collusive negotiations led by experienced and competent counsel.  ECF No. 81 
i
rts fo
iD tc 15  at 13-14.  No objections to the settlement have been filed or brought to the parties’ or the Court’s 
 sir
et
tatsiD 16  attention.  ECF No. 82 at 3.  Defendant has no objection to final approval of the settlement 
S d nr
ee 17  agreement.  ECF No. 83 at 2.  The Court incorporates here its reasons for granting preliminary 
th
intr
Uo
N 18  approval of the settlement, and finds that the settlement is fair, adequate, and reasonable within the 
19  meaning of Rule 23(e).   
20  C.  Claim Form Procedure 
21  The proposed settlement agreement provides that upon final approval of the agreement, the 
22  parties will send “Request Forms” to individual class members describing the member’s 
23  procedural status with the SSA, informing them of the risks of reopening their claims, informing 
24  them that they can have a representative assist them with their claim, and providing an option to 
25  submit a different address.  ECF No. 81 at 15; ECF No. 76 at 24-25.  The forms shall be sent to 
26  the class members’ last known address in accordance with the terms of the agreement.  See ECF 
27  No. 76 at 24-25.   
28 
4 

Case 3:15-cv-00623-JST   Document 88   Filed 04/17/17   Page 5 of 5
 
1  CONCLUSION 
2  The Court finds the settlement agreement fair, adequate, and reasonable and GRANTS 
3  Plaintiffs motion for final approval of the settlement.   
4  The parties shall distribute the Request Forms by May 19, 2017.   
5  Defendant will pay $490,000 in attorneys’ fees and costs to Plaintiffs’ counsel Justice in 
6  Aging and Legal Aid Society of San Mateo County.  The Court finds that this award is fair and 
7  reasonable in light of the nature of this Action, counsel’s experience and efforts in prosecuting and 
8  resolving this action, and the benefits obtained for the Class.  Plaintiffs’ co-counsel, Morrison & 
9  Foerster, has agreed to waive its fees and costs.   
10  The Court reserves exclusive and continuing jurisdiction over the Action, the Class 
11  Representatives, the Class members, and Defendants for the purposes of supervising the 
12  implementation, enforcement, and construction of the Settlement and this Judgment. 
 
a
tr in
uoro 13  IT IS SO ORDERED.

documents.title: Order Denying Motion to Dismiss
documents.text:
1   
2   
3   
4  UNITED STATES DISTRICT COURT 
5  NORTHERN DISTRICT OF CALIFORNIA 
6   
KEVIN HART, et al., 
7  Case No.  15-cv-00623-JST    
Plaintiffs,   
8  ORDER DENYING MOTION TO 
v.  DISMISS 
9   
CAROLYN W. COLVIN,  Re: ECF No. 18 
10 
Defendant. 
11 
   
12   
 
a
tr in
uoro 13  This is a putative class action about the evidence that Administrative Law Judges 
Cfi
 tla
cC 14  (“ALJ’s”) may properly consider in determining whether claimants are entitled to disability 
i
rts fo
iD tc 15  benefits from the Social Security Administration (“SSA”).  Plaintiffs have sued Defendant 
 sir
et
tatsiD 16  Carolyn W. Colvin in her capacity as Acting Commissioner of Social Security, ECF No. 1, 
S d nr
ee 17  challenging the SSA’s alleged reliance on consultative examinations (CEs) performed by Dr. 
th
intr
Uo
N 18  Frank Chen, a physician who is now disqualified, in denying or terminating disability benefits.  Id. 
19  at ¶ 1.  Plaintiffs seek declaratory and injunctive relief requiring the SSA to cease relying on Dr. 
20  Chen’s reports and requiring it to reopen any benefits determination that relied, at least in part, on 
21  a report prepared by Dr. Chen.  Id. at 23-24. 
22    Defendant now moves to dismiss Plaintiffs’ complaint for lack of subject matter 
23  jurisdiction pursuant to Federal Rule of Civil Procedure 12(b)(1).  ECF No. 18.  She contends that 
24  the Court cannot exercise jurisdiction over this case pursuant to 42 U.S.C. § 405(g) because 
25  Plaintiffs have failed to exhaust their administrative remedies through the Social Security 
26  Administration’s internal appeals process.  Plaintiffs respond that this Court should waive the 
27  exhaustion requirement of Section 405(g), because Plaintiffs’ claims are collateral to their claims 
28  for benefits, administrative exhaustion would be futile, and Plaintiffs have made a colorable 

 
1  showing of irreparable harm.  ECF No. 25.  This matter came for a hearing on June 25, 2015. 
2  For the reasons set forth below, the Court concludes that administrative exhaustion would 
3  be futile, and that Plaintiffs have satisfied the other requirements for waiver of the exhaustion 
4  requirement.  The Court therefore denies Defendant’s motion to dismiss.   
5  I.  Background1 
6  To to obtain benefits based on disability under the Supplemental Security Income (SSI) 
7  program or Social Security Disability Insurance (SSDI), a claimant must be unable “to engage in 
8  any substantial gainful activity by reason of any medically determinable physical or mental 
9  impairment which can be expected to result in death or which has lasted or can be expected to last 
10  for a continuous period of not less than 12 months.”  ECF No. 1 at ¶ 2 (citing 42 U.S.C. § 
11  423(d)(1)(A)).  The regulations promulgated pursuant to the Social Security Act require that 
12  claimants provide the Social Security Administration (SSA) with “evidence from acceptable 
 
a
tr in
uoro 13  medical sources to establish whether [an individual has] a medically determinable impairment(s).”  
Cfi
 tla
cC 14  Id. at ¶ 3 (citing 20 C.F.R. § 404.1513(a)).  Although the SSA administers SSI and SSDI, it 
i
rts fo
iD tc 15  contracts with state agencies, such as the Disability Determination Service Division of the 
 sir
et
tatsiD 16  California Department of Social Services (DDSD), in order to make disability determinations.  Id. 
S d nr
ee 17  at ¶ 80.  
th
intr
Uo
N 18  Consultative examinations (CEs) are examinations performed by doctors or other medical 
19  professionals who contract with DDSD.  Id. at ¶ 85.  Following CEs, the examiner will send their 
20  report on a claimant to the DDSD.  Id. at ¶ 87.  The SSA has promulgated various guidelines 
21  regarding the standards for CEs and the consideration of CE reports.  Id. at ¶¶ 88-93. 
22  Named Plaintiffs Kevin Hart, Nina Silva-Collins, and Lee Harris all sought the award or 
23  renewal of disability benefits from the SSA.  Dr. Frank Chen performed consultative examinations 
24  (CEs) on all of the Named Plaintiffs in connection with their application for award or renewal of 
25  disability benefits.  Named Plaintiffs allege various deficiencies with these examinations.    
26    Plaintiff Hart suffered from “tremendous pain and limited mobility,” following a 2007 car 
27 
                                                 
1 For the purposes of this order, the Court accepts as true all of the well-pled factual allegations 
28 
contained in Plaintiff’s Complaint.  ECF No. 1. 
2 

 
1  accident, as well as “diabetes and emphysema.”  Id. at ¶ 17.  Hart was found disabled by an ALJ in 
2  April 2010.  Id. at ¶ 23.  In April of 2013, Hart was attacked violently, exacerbating his pre-
3  existing pain and causing additional serious health conditions.  Id. at ¶ 24-25.  Hart was scheduled 
4  for a continuing disability review in 2013, and referred to Dr. Chen.  Id. at ¶ 26.  Dr. Chen’s 
5  August 15, 2013 examination of Plaintiff Hart lasted only ten minutes.  Id. at ¶¶ 28.  Dr. Chen 
6  submitted a report that misidentified Hart’s complaints and claimed that he had performed tests 
7  that he had not actually performed during his examination.  Id. at ¶¶ 29-32.  The SSA relied on Dr. 
8  Chen’s evaluation in terminating Hart’s benefits on September 11, 2013.  Id. at ¶ 34.  Following a 
9  subsequent hearing, a Disability Hearing Officer concluded in a March 17, 2014 order that Hart’s 
10  physical impairments had “medically improved” and that Hart was “able to do medium work 
11  activities” based upon Dr. Chen’s report.  Id.  at ¶ 35.  The Officer found Dr. Chen’s report “more 
12  reasonable as consistent and supported by medical evidence” than another doctor’s report that had 
 
a
tr in
uoro 13  been submitted by Hart.  Id. at ¶ 35.   
Cfi
 tla
cC 14  Plaintiff Silva-Collins suffers from “severe, chronic anemia caused by menorrhagia 
i
rts fo
iD tc 15  (abnormally heavy and prolonged menstrual bleeding), lumbar degenerative disc disease, 
 sir
et
tatsiD 16  depression, anxiety, asthma, and hypertension.”  Id. at ¶ 38.  Silva-Collins was examined by Dr. 
S d nr
ee 17  Chen on August 10, 2013, after the ALJ determined that a CE was necessary to evaluate her 
th
intr
Uo
N 18  claims.  Id. at ¶ 41.  Dr. Chen’s examination of Silva-Collins lasted for only ten minutes.  Id. at ¶ 
19  42.  Dr. Chen diagnosed Silva-Collins with “[l]ow back pain, possibly due to obesity,” and 
20  “obesity.”  Id. at ¶ 44.  Dr. Chen’s report claimed that Dr. Chen had completed various strength 
21  and range of motion tests that he never actually performed.  Id. at ¶ 45.  “Dr. Chen did not ask Ms. 
22  Silva-Collins any questions about her menorrhagia, anemia, or other blood issues, or the effect that 
23  these chronic conditions had on her physical capabilities.”  Id. at ¶ 43.  On January 8, 2014, the 
24  ALJ denied Silva-Collins’ claim for benefits, giving “great weight to the opinion of consultative 
25  examiner Dr. Chen” and observing that Dr. Chen’s “examination is the most thorough and detailed 
26  in the record, and well supported by the medical evidence as a whole.”  Id. at ¶ 47.  
27    Plaintiff Harris suffers from debilitating lower back, leg, and foot pain following an April 
28  2005 car accident.  Id. at ¶ 53.  Following his August 2011 application for SSI benefits, the SSA 
3 

 
1  referred Plaintiff Harris to Dr. Chen for a CE, which was conducted on October 28, 2011.  Id. at ¶ 
2  56.  The examination lasted twelve minutes.  Id. at ¶ 58.  Dr. Chen instructed Harris to stand 
3  without his cane and Harris responded that he could not do so without support.  Id. at ¶ 60.  
4  Nonetheless, “Dr. Chen concluded that Mr. Harris did not need to use his cane to walk short 
5  distances, even though he had never seen Mr. Harris stand without it.”  Id. at ¶ 63.  Harris’s 
6  application was denied on November 18, 2011 and again on reconsideration on May 16, 2012.  Id. 
7  at ¶ 64.  Although Harris succeeded in obtaining a hearing before an ALJ in April 2013, the ALJ 
8  denied the claim, stating that “the examination by Dr. Chen indicates far greater functionality than 
9  alleged by the claimant.”  Id. at ¶ 65.  The ALJ gave “the greatest weight to Dr. Chen’s opinion 
10  because he personally examined the claimant.”  Id.  
11    Unbeknownst to claimants who were being referred to Dr. Chen for CEs during this time, 
12  DDSD had sent Dr. Chen a Corrective Action letter regarding deficiencies in his CEs in 
 
a
tr in
uoro 13  September 2011.  Id. at ¶ 74.  DDSD sent Dr. Chen a second letter on October 14, 2013, 
Cfi
 tla
cC 14  identifying continuing issues with the quality of his reports.  Id. at ¶ 75.  On December 30, 2013, 
i
rts fo
iD tc 15  following years of complaints from applicants and their representatives regarding Dr. Chen’s 
 sir
et
tatsiD 16  practices, the DDSD removed Dr. Chen from the CE panel, citing Dr. Chen’s “unprofessional 
S d nr
ee 17  manner and failure to adequately correct deficiencies in his CE reports.”  Id. at ¶ 76.  Although Dr. 
th
intr
Uo
N 18  Chen’s reports were a part of the record in all of Plaintiffs’ ongoing challenges to their denial of 
19  disability benefits, Plaintiffs were not provided with notice that Dr. Chen had been removed from 
20  the CE panel.  Id. at ¶ 77. 
21     Plaintiffs ask that this Court assume jurisdiction over this case, certify a class action, and 
22  grant declaratory and injunctive relief: 1) declaring that Defendant’s reliance on Dr. Chen’s CE 
23  reports “violate[s] the SSA’s obligations pursuant to the Social Security Act, its implementing 
24  regulations and the Due Process Clause of the United States Constitution”;  2) enjoining 
25  Defendant from relying on CE reports prepared by Dr. Chen to terminate or deny disability 
26  benefits; 3) requiring Defendant to reopen prior determinations terminating or denying benefits in 
27  reliance on CE reports prepared by Dr. Chen; and 4) requiring Defendant to provide notice to all 
28  individuals whose benefits were terminated or denied in reliance on a CE report prepared by Dr. 
4 

 
1  Chen.  Id. at 23-24.  
2  II.  Legal Standard 
3    The Social Security Act permits claimants to challenge the denial of social security 
4  benefits in a federal District Court after a “final decision” is rendered by the Commissioner.  42 
5  U.S.C. § 405(g).  Plaintiffs filing a civil action generally must meet two requirements: 
6  presentment and exhaustion.  Johnson v. Shalala, 2 F.3d 918, 921 (9th Cir. 1993).  Presentment of 
7  a benefits claim to the Commissioner is a jurisdictional requirement, but exhaustion is not; the 
8  exhaustion requirement may therefore be waived by the SSA or the courts.  Id. (citing Matthews v. 
9  Eldridge, 424 U.S. 319, 330 (1975)).   
10    Defendant acknowledges that Plaintiffs have satisfied the jurisdictional requirement by 
11  presenting their claims to the Commissioner.  Plaintiffs concede that they have not exhausted their 
12  claims through the administrative review process, but urge the Court to waive the exhaustion 
 
a
tr in
uoro 13  requirement under the circumstances alleged in the complaint.   
Cfi
 tla
cC 14    The exhaustion requirement embodies the policy of deferring to the SSA “in the first 
i
rts fo
iD tc 15  instance, both because of its superior ‘expertise in administering its own regulations,’ and because 
 sir
et
tatsiD 16  it is generally more efficient to allow the agency, if it can, to resolve disputes concerning the 
S d nr
ee 17  entitlement programs it administers.”  Briggs v. Sullivan, 886 F.2d 1132, 1139 (9th Cir. 1989) 
th
intr
Uo
N 18  (quoting  Bowen v. City of New York, 476 U.S. 467, 485 (1986)).  Nevertheless, “cases may arise 
19  where a claimant’s interest in having a particular issue resolved promptly is so great that deference 
20  to the agency’s judgment is inappropriate.”  Eldridge, 424 U.S. at 330. 
21    A court may waive the exhaustion requirement where the claim to be reviewed is 
22  “(1) collateral to a substantive claim of entitlement (collaterality), (2) colorable in its showing that 
23  refusal to the relief sought will cause an injury which retroactive payments cannot remedy 
24  (irreparability), and (3) one whose resolution would not serve the purposes of exhaustion 
25  (futility).”  Briggs v. Sullivan, 886 F.2d 1132, 1139 (9th Cir.1989) (citing Eldridge, 424 U.S. at 
26  330) (internal quotations omitted).  All three elements must be met.  See Kaiser v. Blue Cross of 
27  Cal., 347 F.3d 1107, 1115–16 (9th Cir. 2003).  However, “[t]he ultimate decision of whether to 
28  waive exhaustion should not be made solely by mechanical application of the Eldridge factors, but 
5 

 
1  should also be guided by the policies underlying the exhaustion requirement.”  City of New York, 
2  476 U.S. at 484.   
3  III.  Analysis  
4    A.   Irreparability  
5    A plaintiff satisfies the irreparability requirement by making a claim that is “colorable in 
6  its showing that refusal to the relief sought will cause an injury which retroactive payments cannot 
7  remedy.”  Briggs, 886 F.2d at 1139.  A claimant states such a colorable claim where they allege 
8  that “because of [their] physical condition and dependency upon the disability benefits, an 
9  erroneous termination would damage [them] in a way not recompensable through retroactive 
10  payments.”  Eldridge, 424 U.S. at 331.  The Ninth Circuit has held that back payment of benefits 
11  cannot “erase either the experience or the entire effect of several months without food, shelter or 
12  other necessities.”  Briggs, 886 F.2d at 1140.  Accordingly, courts have found irreparability where 
 
a
tr in
uoro 13  a plaintiff has pled that they were living with their elderly mother while awaiting approval of their 
Cfi
 tla
cC 14  SSI application, because they had no other income, Johnson, 2 F.3d at 920, or alleged reliance on 
i
rts fo
iD tc 15  General Assistance and food stamps, a lack of medical insurance, and homelessness.  Kildare, 325 
 sir
et
tatsiD 16  F.3d at 1083.   
S d nr
ee 17    The Court concludes that Plaintiffs have sufficiently demonstrated that their alleged 
th
intr
UoN 18  injuries are irreparable.2  Each Named Plaintiff has pled facts indicating the denial of benefits 
19  represents a grave hardship to him or her for which back payments would not fully compensate.  
20  The complaint states that Plaintiff Hart currently lives with his elderly mother and struggled to 
21  afford basic needs even while he was receiving SSI and SSDI benefits, ECF No. 1 at ¶ 37, Plaintiff 
22  Silva-Collins lives with her father and requires SSI in order to afford necessary medical supplies, 
23  id. at ¶ 52, and Plaintiff Harris is currently dependent on family support to afford food and other 
24  basic life necessities.  Id. at ¶ 70.    
25    Plaintiffs’ claims are colorable in their showing that refusal to the relief sought will cause 
26  an injury which retroactive payments cannot remedy. 
27 
                                                 
2 Defendant does not argue that Plaintiffs have failed to make a colorable showing of 
28 
irreparability.   
6 

 
1    B.  Collaterality 
2    “A plaintiff’s claim is collateral if it is not essentially a claim for benefits.”  Johnson, 2 
3  F.3d at 921.  Plaintiffs argue that they are not asking the Court to award or reinstate benefits as a 
4  result of this litigation, but instead ask for injunctive relief that would require the SSA to reopen 
5  proceedings that erroneously relied on Dr. Chen’s reports to terminate or deny benefits.   ECF No. 
6  25 at 8.  Defendant contends that, despite Plaintiffs’ “artful attempt to frame their claims as a 
7  challenge to an alleged SSA ‘policy and practice,’” ECF No. 18 at 15, Plaintiffs in fact seek to 
8  advance their claims for benefits by challenging Dr. Chen’s reports.  Id. at 16.  Defendant finds it 
9  significant that the Complaint challenges Defendant’s “policy and practice of relying on Dr. 
10  Chen’s defective CE reports in denying or terminating benefits,” and argues that this demonstrates 
11  that “Plaintiffs do not challenge a ‘policy’ but are, instead, challenging a specific outcome– denial 
12  of benefits– in cases where Dr. Chen prepared reports.”  ECF No. 27 at 7 (quoting ECF No. 1 at ¶ 
 
a
tr in
uoro 13  7).   
Cfi
 tla
cC 14    The fact that Plaintiffs challenge the SSA’s use of Dr. Chen’s reports in cases that resulted 
i
rts fo
iD tc 15  in denials of claims for benefits does not convert Plaintiffs’ challenge into a claim for benefits.  In 
 sir
et
tatsiD 16  City of New York, the Supreme Court held that a challenge to the SSA’s presumption that 
S d nr
ee 17  mentally disabled applicants were qualified to do unskilled work was collateral to a claim for 
th
intr
Uo
N 18  benefits.  476 U.S. 467.  The Court reasoned that “[t]he class members neither sought nor were 
19  awarded benefits in the District Court, but rather challenged the Secretary’s failure to follow the 
20  applicable regulations.”  Id. at 483.  The Court reached this conclusion even though Plaintiffs 
21  challenged the SSA’s use of a blanket presumption that “led to routine denials of benefits to 
22  eligible claimants.”  Id. at 473 (emphasis added).  Likewise, in Johnson, the Ninth Circuit held that 
23  plaintiffs’ challenge to “the Secretary’s policy of treating as income all in-kind loans” was 
24  collateral to their claims for benefits.  2 F.3d at 921.  The Court observed that plaintiffs had 
25  “sought the invalidation of a rule used to determine eligibility for benefits rather than the denial of 
26  benefits in a particular case.”  Id.  The Johnson court acknowledged that a favorable decision for 
27  plaintiffs would require the Secretary to “readjudicate those claims that were denied under the in-
28  kind policy.”  Id.  (emphasis added).  But, the court concluded that, while adjudication would 
7 

 
1  mean that “[s]ome claimants will receive benefits they were once denied,” other claimants would 
2  continue to be denied benefits as “[t]hey would not be entitled to benefits under either policy,” 
3  demonstrating plaintiffs’ claims were collateral.  Id.   
4    Plaintiffs’ claims in this case are collateral to their claims for benefits because they do not 
5  challenge the outcome of the SSA proceedings—the denial or termination of their SSI or SSDI 
6  benefits.  Rather, they challenge the process by which that outcome was reached—in reliance on 
7  Dr. Chen’s CE reports.  It is of no moment to the analysis that, should Plaintiffs be granted the 
8  relief they seek, the outcome of their disability claims might ultimately prove different.  This was 
9  also true of the Plaintiffs in City of New York and Johnson, who alleged that procedural 
10  deficiencies occasioned the wrongful denial of their claims for benefits.  All that Plaintiffs seek 
11  from this Court is relief mandating that the SSA not use Dr. Chen’s CE reports in the process of 
12  evaluating Plaintiffs’ disability claims.  In the event that Plaintiffs are entitled to such relief at the 
 
a
tr in
uoro 13  close of the litigation, their ultimate entitlement to benefits will still be unknown and left to be 
Cfi
 tla
cC 14  resolved by the SSA.   
i
rts fo
iD tc 15    Defendant also contends that Plaintiffs’ claims are not collateral to their claims for benefits 
 sir
et
tatsiD 16  because there is no SSA-wide “policy” to rely on Dr. Chen’s reports in resolving disability claims.  
S d nr
ee 17  Defendant asserts that SSA adjudicators resolve disability claims on a case-by-case basis, and 
th
intr
Uo
N 18  “must decide the degree of weight, if any, to afford that report in determining whether the claimant 
19  is disabled.”  ECF No. 27 at 5.  Therefore, “[a]pplication of SSA’s regulations in a particular case 
20  may result in a degree of ‘reliance’ [on Dr. Chen’s reports] by the adjudicator, or it may not, all 
21  depending on the particular circumstances of the case.”  Id.   
22  Defendant argues that this case resembles Kildare, where the Ninth Circuit concluded that 
23  plaintiffs’ claims were not collateral to claims for benefits when plaintiffs had alleged “a series of 
24  claimed irregularities in individual cases that [were] entirely dependent on the [plaintiffs’] 
25  underlying claims for benefits.”  325 F.3d at 1083.  Although the plaintiffs in that case had used 
26  terms such as “policy,” “practice,” and “systematic” throughout their complaint, the Kildare court 
27  observed that the plaintiffs had “admitted in their brief that they cannot point to any specific 
28  policy, directive, or order” that had resulted in the alleged erroneous denial of plaintiffs’ claims.  
8 

 
1  Id.  But Plaintiffs in this case do not merely allege “idiosyncratic individual errors,” as was the 
2  case in Kildare, id.; they point to an SSA-wide policy to consider Dr. Chen’s reports in resolving 
3  disability claims, even in the wake of widespread allegations of deficiencies in the quality of his 
4  examinations.   
5  Defendant’s reply brief points to a March 16, 2015,3 letter from the Chief Administrative 
6  Law Judge for the SSA to the Acting Chief Administrative Law Judge for San Francisco providing 
7  guidance to adjudicators regarding Dr. Chen and instructing them to “consider” Dr. Chen’s 
8  removal from the panel in “determining the weight, if any, to which” Dr. Chen’s CE is entitled.  
9  ECF No. 27-2 at 2-3.  Defendant offers this letter in an attempt to show that the SSA is aware of 
10  the serious issues with Dr. Chen’s CE reports and has instructed its adjudicators to factor these 
11  concerns into the case-by-case review of Plaintiffs’ disability claims.  But this letter only 
12  underscores the existence of an SSA-wide policy regarding Dr. Chen, authorizing adjudicators to 
 
a
tr in
uoro 13  continue to “consider” his CE reports following his removal from the CE panel.4   
Cfi
 tla
cC 14    Plaintiffs do not seek an award of benefits from this Court.  Instead, Plaintiffs seek 
i
rts fo
iD tc 15  injunctive relief mandating that the SSA cannot rely on Dr. Chen’s reports in resolving disability 
 sir
et
tatsiD 16  claims going forward and requiring the SSA to reopen terminations or denials of disability claims 
S d nr
ee 17  that relied on CEs performed by Dr. Chen.  Therefore, Plaintiffs’ claims challenge a policy and are 
th
intr
Uo
N 18  collateral to their claims for benefits.   
19    C.  Futility 
20    The Ninth Circuit has held that a claimant can demonstrate futility by showing that 
21  “[r]equiring him to exhaust administrative remedies would not serve the policies underlying 
22  exhaustion.”  Briggs, 886 F.2d at 1140 (quoting Cassim v. Bowen, 824 F.2d 791, 795 (9th Cir. 
23  1987)).  For instance, “[w]hen the agency applies a ‘systemwide policy’ that is ‘inconsistent in 
24  critically important ways with established regulations,’ nothing is gained ‘from permitting the 
25 
                                                 
26 
3 The complaint in this case was filed February 9, 2015.   
4 Defendant submitted this letter as evidence for the first time in connection with her reply brief.  
27 
The Court generally does not consider new evidence presented for the first time on reply.  In re 
Hansen Natural Corp. Sec. Litig., 527 F. Supp. 2d 1142, 1150 (C.D. Cal. 2007).  The Court will 
28 
consider the letter in this instance, however, because no prejudice to the Plaintiffs will result.   
9 

 
1  compilation of a detailed factual record, or from agency expertise.’”  Johnson, 2 F.3d at 922 
2  (quoting City of New York, 476 U.S. at 484).  A Court’s conclusion that it is “unlikely that an 
3  individual claimant could have succeeded in having the Secretary’s policy overturned or his 
4  benefits restored through the administrative process” also supports a finding of futility, as in such 
5  a case “[r]equiring each individual to exhaust his administrative remedies would result in a 
6  considerable waste of judicial resources.”  Id.  In contrast, when alleged “errors require 
7  interpretation of the regulations and vary with each Appellant, the errors must be determined in the 
8  context of individual disability proceeding and require development of individual factual records.”  
9  Kildare, 325 F.3d at 1084. 
10    Plaintiffs argue that exhaustion would be futile as “a more fully developed factual record, 
11  or agency expertise” would not assist the Court in resolving the purely legal issue of whether 
12  continued reliance on Dr. Chen’s CE reports violates SSA’s legal obligations.  ECF No. 25 at 13.  
 
a
tr in
uoro 13  Defendant counters that the extent to which the adjudicator relied on Dr. Chen’s report varies 
Cfi
 tla
cC 14  depending on the claimant, necessitating the development of an individualized factual record.  
i
rts fo
iD tc 15  Defendant also argues that administrative exhaustion would not be futile because individual 
 sir
et
tatsiD 16  Plaintiffs could prevail on administrative appeal of their denial or termination of benefits.  
S d nr
ee 17  Defendant states that “SSA’s review process is capable of vacating any instances of improper 
th
intr
Uo
N 18  reliance, ordering new consultative examinations, or awarding benefits to meritorious claimants.”  
19  ECF No. 27 at 9.   
20    Defendant attempts to bolster her argument that administrative exhaustion would not be 
21  futile by noting that, following the filing of the complaint in this case, the ALJ in Hart’s 
22  administrative review provided Hart “with a new consultative examination from an internist other 
23  than Dr. Chen.”  ECF No. 18 at 17.  Defendant argues that “Plaintiff Hart cannot plausibly argue 
24  that there is ‘nothing to be gained’ from administrative exhaustion when he has received the very 
25  thing he asked this Court to order.”  Id.  Defendant has also notified the Court that the Appeals 
26  Council in Plaintiff Silva-Collins internal appeal has recently remanded her case back to the ALJ 
27 
28 
10 

 
1  for further proceedings.5  The Appeals Council reasoned that because the ALJ had given “great 
2  weight” to Dr. Chen’s CE, despite the CE’s “inconsistent opinions regarding the claimant’s 
3  functional limitations,” the ALJ was required to engage in “additional development and evaluation 
4  of the evidence” in order to determine the claimant’s residual functional capacity.  ECF No. 34-1 
5  at 8.  The Appeals Council noted that the ALJ a new CE “may be particularly helpful” to evaluate 
6  Plaintiff’s residual functional capacity, but did not require the ALJ to order one.  Id.  Although the 
7  Council noted the inconsistencies in Dr. Chen’s report and his recent disqualification, the Appeals 
8  Council did not instruct the ALJ as to whether it could continue to consider Dr. Chen’s CE on 
9  remand.  Id. at 8-10. 
10    Defendant argues that these orders demonstrate that Plaintiffs should be required to 
11  exhaust the administrative process before bringing this suit, as the SSA internal appeals process is 
12  aware of Dr. Chen’s disqualification and likely to grant affected claimants relief.  But Plaintiffs do 
 
a
tr in
uoro 13  not ask this Court merely to order the SSA to provide a new CE report in their particular cases or 
Cfi
 tla
cC 14  to instruct ALJ’s to examine Dr. Chen’s reports critically for potential inconsistencies; they urge 
i
rts fo
iD tc 15  that Dr. Chen’s reports are so unreliable that they should not be relied upon at all in the 
 sir
et
tatsiD 16  administrative review of their disability claims.  As Plaintiffs assert forcefully in their opposition, 
S d nr
ee 17  “[t]he fact that Mr. Hart, or any other Plaintiff, may receive a new CE does not ensure that the 
th
intr
Uo
N 18  prior CE report from Dr. Chen will be excluded in the decision of whether the claimant is entitled 
19  to benefits.”  ECF No. 25 at 13.  Indeed, even after Hart’s new CE, an ALJ could decide “that the 
20  new CE report is less consistent with the evidence as a whole, including the improper and 
21  misleading CE report by Dr. Chen, and make a determination to deny or terminate benefits on that 
22  basis.”  Id.   
23    Because Plaintiffs challenge an SSA-wide policy of continuing to use Dr. Chen’s reports in 
24  evaluating claimants, there is nothing to be gained “from permitting the compilation of a detailed 
25  factual record.”  Johnson, 2 F.3d at 922.  Indeed, the SSA has already informed the Court of how 
26 
                                                 
5 Following the hearing on this motion, Defendant submitted an unopposed administrative motion 
27 
seeking to file notice of an Appeals Council order that was entered in Plaintiff Silva-Collins 
administrative appeal.  ECF No. 34.  As the motion is unopposed, the Court will consider the 
28 
appeals council order.   
11 

 
1  it intends to respond to the issues with Dr. Chen’s reports:  it has directed adjudicators to 
2  “consider” Dr. Chen’s removal from the CE panel “when evaluating a report from Dr. Chen and 
3  determining the weight, if any, to which it is entitled,” ECF No. 27-2 at 3, and it has instructed 
4  adjudicators to “consider whether ordering an additional CE is appropriate.”  Id.  Such remedial 
5  action falls well short of the relief requested in the Complaint.  Therefore, requiring all putative 
6  class members to exhaust their administrative appeals “would result in a considerable waste of 
7  judicial resources,” Johnson, 2 F.3d at 922, as Defendant has already stated the SSA’s intention to 
8  continue to consider Dr. Chen’s reports in appeals of disability denials or terminations.   
9    The Court therefore concludes that requiring Plaintiffs to exhaust administrative remedies 
10  would not serve the policies underlying exhaustion.  Briggs, 886 F.2d at 1140   
11  IV.  Conclusion   
12    Because Plaintiffs have shown that waiver of Section 405(g)’s exhaustion requirement is 
 
a
tr in
uoro 13  appropriate under the circumstances, the Court will deny Defendant’s motion to dismiss the 
Cfi
 tclaC 14  Complaint pursuant to Federal Rule of Civil Procedure 12(b)(1).6   
i
rts fo
iD tc 15  IT IS SO ORDERED. 
 sir
et
tatsiD 16  Dated:  July 17, 2015 
S d nr ______________________________________ 
ee 17 
tinhtr JON S. TIGAR 
UoN 18  United States District Judge 
 
19 
20 
21 
22 
23 
24 
25 
26 
                                                 
27 
6 Because the Court concludes that the exhaustion requirement is properly waived as to all of 
Plaintiffs’ causes of action, the Court need not address the parties’ arguments regarding whether 
28 
Plaintiffs’ third cause of action for violations of due process confers subject matter jurisdiction.

4  UNITED STATES DISTRICT COURT 
5  NORTHERN DISTRICT OF CALIFORNIA 
6   
KEVIN HART, et al.,  Case No. 15-cv-00623-JST    
7 
 
Plaintiffs, 
8  ORDER GRANTING MOTION FOR 
PRELIMINARY APPROVAL OF CLASS 
v. 
9  ACTION SETTLEMENT 
 
CAROLYN W. COLVIN,  Re: ECF No. 75 
10 
Defendant.
