12  Before the Court is Plaintiffs’ unopposed Motion for Preliminary Approval of Class Action 
 
a
tr in
uoro 13  Settlement.  ECF Nos. 75, 79.1  For the reasons set forth below, the Court grants the motion.  
Cfi
 tla
cC 14  I.  BACKGROUND 
i
rts fo
iD tc 15  A.  Factual Background 
 sir
et
tatsiD 16    This is a putative class action about the evidence that Administrative Law Judges (“ALJs”) 
S d nr
ee 17  may properly consider in determining whether claimants are entitled to disability benefits from the 
th
intr
Uo
N 18  Social Security Administration (“SSA”).  ECF No. 50.  Named Plaintiffs Kevin Hart, Nina Silva-
19  Collins, and Lee Harris represent a class of individuals who received a consultative examination 
20  (“CE”) performed by Dr. Frank Chen, a physician who is now disqualified, in connection with 
21  their applications for award or review of disability benefits from the SSA.  ECF No. 50; ECF No. 
22  1 ¶¶ 13-15.  Defendant Carolyn W. Colvin is the Acting Commissioner of Social Security.   
23  To obtain benefits based on disability under the Supplemental Security Income (“SSI”) or 
24  Social Security Disability Insurance (“SSDI”) programs, a claimant must be unable “to engage in 
25  any substantial gainful activity by reason of any medically determinable physical or mental 
26 
                                                 
1 On November 8, 2016, the parties filed a Notice of Amended Settlement Agreement, which is 
27 
the agreement currently before the Court.  The only amendment was a change in the notice by 
publication term of the settlement to specify the publications in which notice will be published.  
28 
The change is sensible, is not material, and does not require further discussion.   

 
1  impairment which can be expected to result in death or which has lasted or can be expected to last 
2  for a continuous period of not less than 12 months.”  ECF No. 1 ¶ 2 (citing 42 U.S.C. § 
3  423(d)(1)(A)).  SSA, which administers the SSI and SSDI programs, is required to “establish by 
4  regulation uniform standards which shall be applied at all levels of determination, review, and 
5  adjudication in determining whether individuals are under disabilities.”  42 U.S.C. § 421(k)(1).  
6  The regulations promulgated pursuant to the Social Security Act require that claimants provide 
7  SSA with “evidence from acceptable medical sources to establish whether [an individual has] a 
8  medically determinable impairment(s).”  ECF No. 1 ¶ 3 (citing 20 C.F.R. § 404.1513(a)).  
9  “Objective medical evidence of pain or other symptoms established by medically acceptable 
10  clinical or laboratory techniques . . . must be considered in reaching a conclusion as to whether [a 
11  claimant] is under a disability.”  42 U.S.C. § 423(d)(5)(A).   
12  Although SSA administers SSI and SSDI, it contracts with state agencies, such as the 
 
a
tr in
uoro 13  Disability Determination Service Division of the California Department of Social Services 
Cfi
 tla
cC 14  (“DDSD”), to make disability determinations.  Id. ¶ 80.  If DDSD cannot get the information it 
i
rts fo
iD tc 15  needs to make a disability determination from a claimant’s own medical records, DDSD may 
 sir
et
tatsiD 16  decide to purchase a consultative examination (“CE”).  20 C.F.R. § 404.1519a.  CEs are 
S d nr
ee 17  examinations performed by doctors or other medical professionals who contract with DDSD.  ECF 
th
intr
Uo
N 18  No. 1 ¶ 85.  Following a CE, the examiner sends a report regarding the claimant to DDSD.  Id.       
19  ¶ 87.  SSA has promulgated various guidelines regarding the standards for CEs and the 
20  consideration of CE reports.  Id. ¶¶ 88–93.  In particular, SSA regulations require that evidence 
21  used in making disability determinations, such as CE reports, must come from “acceptable 
22  medical sources.”  20 C.F.R. §§ 404.1513(a), 404.1519(g).  “Acceptable medical sources” include 
23  “[l]icensed physician[s].”  Id. §§ 404.1513(a)(1), 416.913(a)(1).  
24  SSA regulations require adjudicators to “always consider” CE reports along with the rest 
25  of the relevant evidence in making a disability determination.  Id. §§ 404.1527(b), 416.927(b); see 
26  also ECF No. 46 at 3.  “Regardless of its source, [SSA adjudicators] will evaluate every medical 
27  opinion,” including every CE, the adjudicator receives in light of multiple factors to “determine[e] 
28  the weight,” if any, the opinion should be given.  20 C.F.R. §§ 404.1527(c)(2), 416.927(b).  Even 
2 

 
1  after an examiner has been disqualified, SSA regulations permit adjudicators to rely on existing 
2  CE reports prepared by the disqualified examiner.  ECF No. 1 at ¶ 99 (citing 20 C.F.R. §§ 
3  404.1503, 416.903a (“We will not use in our program any individual or entity, except to provide 
4  existing medical evidence, who is currently excluded, suspended, or otherwise barred from 
5  participation in . . . any other Federal or Federally-assisted program.”)). 
6  Named Plaintiffs Kevin Hart, Nina Silva-Collins, and Lee Harris all sought the award or 
7  renewal of disability benefits from SSA.  Dr. Frank Chen performed CEs on all of the Named 
8  Plaintiffs in connection with their applications for award or renewal of disability benefits.  Named 
9  Plaintiffs allege various deficiencies with these examinations.    
10    Plaintiff Hart suffered from “tremendous pain and limited mobility,” following a 2007 car 
11  accident, as well as “diabetes and emphysema.”  Id. ¶ 17.  Hart was found disabled by an ALJ in 
12  April 2010.  Id. ¶ 23.  In April of 2013, Hart was attacked violently, exacerbating his pre-existing 
 
a
tr in
uoro 13  pain and causing additional serious health conditions.  Id. ¶ 24–25.  Hart was scheduled for a 
Cfi
 tla
cC 14  continuing disability review in 2013 and referred to Dr. Chen.  Id. ¶ 26.  Dr. Chen’s August 15, 
i
rts fo
iD tc 15  2013 examination of Plaintiff Hart lasted only ten minutes.  Id. ¶ 28.  Dr. Chen submitted a report 
 sir
et
tatsiD 16  that misidentified Hart’s complaints and claimed that he had performed tests that he had not 
S d nr
ee 17  actually performed during his examination.  Id. ¶¶ 29–32.  SSA relied on Dr. Chen’s evaluation in 
th
intr
Uo
N 18  terminating Hart’s benefits on September 11, 2013.  Id. ¶ 34.  Following a subsequent hearing, a 
19  Disability Hearing Officer concluded in a March 17, 2014 order that Hart’s physical impairments 
20  had “medically improved” and that Hart was “able to do medium work activities” based upon Dr. 
21  Chen’s report.  Id. ¶ 35.  The Officer found Dr. Chen’s report “more reasonable as consistent and 
22  supported by medical evidence” than another doctor’s report that had been submitted by Hart.  Id. 
23  Plaintiff Silva-Collins suffers from “severe, chronic anemia caused by menorrhagia 
24  (abnormally heavy and prolonged menstrual bleeding), lumbar degenerative disc disease, 
25  depression, anxiety, asthma, and hypertension.”  Id. ¶ 38.  Silva-Collins was examined by Dr. 
26  Chen on August 10, 2013, after an ALJ determined that a CE was necessary to evaluate her 
27  claims.  Id. ¶ 41.  Dr. Chen’s examination of Silva-Collins lasted only ten minutes.  Id. ¶ 42.  Dr. 
28  Chen diagnosed Silva-Collins with “[l]ow back pain, possibly due to obesity,” and “obesity.”  Id.  
3 

 
1  ¶ 44.  Dr. Chen’s report claimed that he had completed various strength and range of motion tests 
2  that he never actually performed.  Id. ¶ 45.  “Dr. Chen did not ask Ms. Silva-Collins any questions 
3  about her menorrhagia, anemia, or other blood issues, or the effect that these chronic conditions 
4  had on her physical capabilities.”  Id. ¶ 43.  On January 8, 2014, the ALJ denied Silva-Collins’ 
5  claim for benefits, giving “great weight to the opinion of consultative examiner Dr. Chen” and 
6  observing that Dr. Chen’s “examination is the most thorough and detailed in the record, and well 
7  supported by the medical evidence as a whole.”  Id. ¶ 47.  
8    Plaintiff Harris suffers from debilitating lower back, leg, and foot pain caused by an April 
9  2005 car accident.  Id. ¶ 53.  Following his August 2011 application for SSI benefits, SSA referred 
10  Plaintiff Harris to Dr. Chen for a CE, which was conducted on October 28, 2011.  Id. ¶ 56.  The 
11  examination lasted twelve minutes.  Id. ¶ 58.  Dr. Chen instructed Harris to stand without his cane, 
12  and Harris responded that he could not do so without support.  Id. ¶ 60.  Nonetheless, “Dr. Chen 
 
a
tr in
uoro 13  concluded that Mr. Harris did not need to use his cane to walk short distances, even though he had 
Cfi
 tla
cC 14  never seen Mr. Harris stand without [the cane].”  Id. ¶ 63.  Harris’s application was denied on 
i
rts fo
iD tc 15  November 18, 2011 and denied again upon reconsideration on May 16, 2012.  Id. ¶ 64.  Although 
 sir
et
tatsiD 16  Harris succeeded in obtaining a hearing before an ALJ in April 2013, the ALJ denied Harris’ 
S d nr
ee 17  claim, stating that “the examination by Dr. Chen indicates far greater functionality than alleged by 
th
intr
Uo
N 18  the claimant.”  Id. ¶ 65.  The ALJ gave “the greatest weight to Dr. Chen’s opinion because he 
19  personally examined the claimant.”  Id.  
20    Unbeknownst to claimants who were being referred to Dr. Chen for CEs during this time, 
21  DDSD had sent Dr. Chen a Corrective Action letter regarding deficiencies in his CEs in 
22  September 2011.  Id. ¶ 74.  DDSD sent Dr. Chen a second letter on October 14, 2013, identifying 
23  continuing issues with the quality of his reports, the lack of thoroughness of his examinations, and 
24  his unprofessional manner towards applicants.  Id. ¶ 75.  On December 30, 2013, following years 
25  of complaints from applicants and their representatives regarding Dr. Chen’s practices, DDSD 
26  removed Dr. Chen from the CE panel, citing Dr. Chen’s “unprofessional manner and failure to 
27  adequately correct deficiencies in his CE reports.”  Id. ¶ 76.  Although Dr. Chen’s reports were a 
28  part of the record in all of Plaintiffs’ ongoing challenges to their denial of disability benefits, 
4 

 
1  Plaintiffs were not provided with notice that Dr. Chen had been removed from the CE panel.  Id.   
2  ¶ 77; see also Defendant’s Answer to Class Action Complaint (“Answer”), ECF No. 38 ¶ 100 
3  (“SSA admits that there is no regulation or rule directing SSA to provide applicants whose 
4  benefits have been denied or terminated notice that the consultative examiner in their case has 
5  been removed from the applicable CE panel.”). 
6    B.  Procedural Background 
7  On February 9, 2015, Plaintiffs filed a Complaint, asking the Court to grant declaratory 
8  and injunctive relief: 1) declaring that Defendant’s reliance on Dr. Chen’s CE reports “violate[s] 
9  the SSA’s obligations pursuant to the Social Security Act, its implementing regulations and the 
10  Due Process Clause of the United States Constitution”; 2) enjoining Defendant from relying on 
11  CE reports prepared by Dr. Chen to terminate or deny disability benefits; 3) requiring Defendant 
12  to reopen prior determinations terminating or denying benefits in reliance on CE reports prepared 
 
a
tr in
uoro 13  by Dr. Chen; and 4) requiring Defendant to provide notice to all individuals whose benefits were 
Cfi
 tla
cC 14  terminated or denied in reliance on a CE report prepared by Dr. Chen of their right to these forms 
i
rts fo
iD tc 15  of relief.  ECF No. 1 at 23–24.  On April 20, 2015, Defendant filed a motion to dismiss for lack of 
 sir
et
tatsiD 16  subject matter jurisdiction, contending that the Court could not exercise jurisdiction over this case 
S de nre 17  pursuant to 42 U.S.C. § 405(g)2 because Plaintiffs have failed to exhaust their administrative 
th
intr
Uo
N 18  remedies through the SSA’s internal appeals process.  ECF No. 18.  On July 17, 2015, the Court 
19  denied Defendant’s motion to dismiss, concluding that administrative exhaustion would be futile 
20  and that Plaintiffs had satisfied the other requirements for waiver of the exhaustion requirement.  
21  ECF No. 36.   
22  On July 31, 2015, Defendant filed her Answer to the Complaint.  ECF No. 38.  On August 
23  6, 2015, Plaintiffs filed a motion for class certification, seeking to certify a class of “[a]ll persons 
24  whose SSI or SSDI benefits were either denied or terminated and for whom a consultative 
25  examination was prepared by Dr. Frank Chen,” ECF No. 40 at 9.  On October 14, 2015, the Court 
26 
                                                 
2 42 U.S.C. § 405(g) provides: “Any individual, after any final decision of the Commissioner of 
27 
Social Security made after a hearing to which he was a party, irrespective of the amount in 
controversy, may obtain a review of such decision by a civil action commenced within sixty days 
28 
after the mailing to him of notice of such decision . . . .” 
5 

 
1  granted the motion for class certification, concluding that Plaintiffs had met the requirements of 
2  Federal Rules of Civil Procedure 23(a) and 23(b)(2).  ECF No. 50.  On September 19, 2016, 
3  Plaintiffs filed an unopposed motion for preliminary approval of class action settlement 
4  agreement, which motion the Court now considers.  ECF No. 75.  
5  II.  CLASS CERTIFICATION 
6    A.  Legal Standard 
7  Class certification under Rule 23 of the Federal Rules of Civil Procedure is a two-step 
8  process.  First, a plaintiff must demonstrate that the four requirements of Rule 23(a) are met: 
9  numerosity, commonality, typicality, and adequacy.  “Class certification is proper only if the trial 
10  court has concluded, after a ‘rigorous analysis,’ that Rule 23(a) has been satisfied.”  Wang v. 
11  Chinese Daily News, Inc., 709 F.3d 829, 833 (9th Cir. 2013) (quoting Wal-Mart Stores, Inc. v. 
12  Dukes, 131 S. Ct. 2541, 2551 (2011)).  
 
a
tr in
uoro 13  Second, a plaintiff must establish that the action meets one of the bases for certification in 
Cfi
 tla
cC 14  Rule 23(b). Here, because they rely on Rule 23(b)(3), Plaintiffs must establish that “questions of 
i
rts fo
iD tc 15  law or fact common to class members predominate over any questions affecting only individual 
 sir
et
tatsiD 16  members, and . . . [that] a class action is superior to other available methods for fairly and 
S d nr
ee 17  efficiently adjudicating the controversy.” Fed. R. Civ. P. 23(b)(3).  
th
intr
Uo
N 18  The party seeking class certification bears the burden of demonstrating by a preponderance 
19  of the evidence that all four requirements of Rule 23(a) and at least one of the three requirements 
20  under Rule 23(b) are met.  See Wal-Mart, 131 S. Ct. at 2551. 
21    B.  Proposed Class Modification 
22    The Court has previously certified a class “consisting of all persons whose SSI or SSDI 
23  benefits were either denied or terminated and for whom a consultative examination was prepared 
24  by Dr. Frank Chen.”  ECF No. 50 at 19.  Solely for purposes of the proposed settlement, as agreed 
25  to by the parties, Plaintiffs request that the class definition be amended to be: 
 
26 
[A]ll persons whose SSI or SSDI benefits were either denied or terminated and for 
whom a consultative examination was prepared by Dr. Frank Chen, and all persons 
27 
who received a partially favorable decision or determination on their claim for SSI 
28  or SSDI benefits and for whom a consultative examination was prepared by Dr. 
6 

 
Chen.  
1 
ECF No. 76 at 5.  Plaintiffs argue that “this is not a substantive change,” and merely includes in 
2 
the class, in explicit terms, “individuals who did not receive an award or benefits for the full 
3 
period of their application—in other words, whose benefits were ‘denied or terminated’ only in 
4 
part.”  Id.  As stated in the Court’s order granting class certification, the alleged wrong in this case 
5 
“is one of process, not outcome,” and resolution does not “depend on the individual facts of each 
6 
Plaintiff’s claims because Plaintiffs argue that any consideration of Dr. Chen’s report whatsoever 
7 
violated the law.”  ECF No. 50 at 10, 14.  Therefore, the Court concludes that Plaintiffs’ requested 
8 
modification is appropriate and does not affect the class’s sufficiency under Rule 23.  The 
9 
modification is approved. 
10 
III.  PRELIMINARY APPROVAL 
11 
  A.  Legal Standard 
12 
 
a
tr in The Ninth Circuit maintains a “strong judicial policy” that favors the settlement of class 
uoro 13 
C tfila actions.  Class Plaintiffs v. City of Seattle, 955 F.2d 1268, 1276 (9th Cir. 1992).  Courts generally 
cC 14 
i
rts fo employ a two-step process in evaluating a class action settlement.  First, courts make a 
iD tc 15 
 seirt “preliminary determination” concerning the merits of the settlement and, if the class action has 
tatsiD 16 
S d nr settled prior to class certification, the propriety of certifying the class.  See Manual for Complex 
ee 17 
th
intr Litigation, Fourth (“MCL, 4th”) § 21.632 (FJC 2004).  “The initial decision to approve or reject a 
Uo
N 18 
settlement proposal is committed to the sound discretion of the trial judge.”  City of Seattle, 955 
19 
F.2d at 1276.  Courts “must be particularly vigilant not only for explicit collusion, but also for 
20 
more subtle signs that class counsel have allowed pursuit of their own self-interests and that of 
21 
certain class members to infect the negotiations.”  In re Bluetooth Headset Prods. Liab. Litig., 654 
22 
F.3d 935, 947 (9th Cir. 2011). 
23 
The Court’s task at the preliminary approval stage is to determine whether the settlement 
24 
falls “within the range of possible approval.”  In re Tableware Antitrust Litig., 484 F. Supp. 2d 
25 
1078, 1080 (N.D. Cal. 2007) (quotation omitted); see also MCL, 4th § 21.632 (explaining that 
26 
courts “must make a preliminary determination on the fairness, reasonableness, and adequacy of 
27 
the settlement terms and must direct the preparation of notice of the certification, proposed 
28 
7 

 
1  settlement, and date of the final fairness hearing.”).  Second, courts must hold a hearing pursuant 
2  to Rule 23(e)(2) to make a final determination of whether the settlement is “fair, reasonable, and 
3  adequate.” 
4  Preliminary approval of a settlement is appropriate if “the proposed settlement appears to 
5  be the product of serious, informed, non-collusive negotiations, has no obvious deficiencies, does 
6  not improperly grant preferential treatment to class representatives or segments of the class, and 
7  falls within the range of possible approval.”  In re Tableware, 484 F. Supp. 2d at 1079 (quotation 
8  omitted).  The proposed settlement need not be ideal, but it must be fair and free of collusion, 
9  consistent with counsel’s fiduciary obligations to the class.  Hanlon v. Chrysler Corp., 150 F.3d 
10  1011, 1027 (9th Cir. 1998) (“Settlement is the offspring of compromise; the question we address is 
11  not whether the final product could be prettier, smarter or snazzier, but whether it is fair, adequate 
12  and free from collusion.”).  To assess a settlement proposal, courts must balance a number of 
 
a
tr in
uoro 13  factors:  
Cfi
 tla  
ciC 14  the strength of the plaintiffs’ case; the risk, expense, complexity, and likely 
rts fo duration of further litigation; the risk of maintaining class action status throughout 
iD tc 15  the trial; the amount offered in settlement; the extent of discovery completed and 
 sir
et the state of the proceedings; the experience and views of counsel; the presence of a 
tatsiD 16  governmental participant; and the reaction of the class members to the proposed 
S d nr settlement.  
ee 17 
th
intr Id. at 1026 (citations omitted).  The proposed settlement must be “taken as a whole, rather than the 
Uo
N 18 
individual component parts” in the examination for overall fairness.  Id.  Courts do not have the 
19 
ability to “delete, modify, or substitute certain provisions”; the settlement “must stand or fall in its 
20 
entirety.”  Id. 
21 
  B.  Settlement Negotiations 
22 
  On August 17, 2015, the Court referred the parties for a Settlement Conference before 
23 
Magistrate Judge Maria-Elena James, scheduled for November 2015.  ECF Nos. 44-45.  The 
24 
parties engaged in settlement discussions in person, by phone, and by email in the intervening 
25 
months.  ECF No. 76 at 4.  The first Settlement Conference took place on November 17, 2015.  
26 
ECF No. 54.  The parties subsequently had six additional Settlement Conferences with Magistrate 
27 
Judge James: on December 18, 2015, April 5, 2016, April 28, 2016, May 19, 2016, July 13, 2016, 
28 
8 

 
1  and July 28, 2016.  ECF Nos. 57, 62, 65, 66, 68, 71.  The parties reached an agreement on 
2  September 19, 2016.  ECF No. 76.    
3    C.  Terms of the Settlement 
4    As described by Plaintiffs, “[t]he Settlement Agreement provides relief to class members 
5  through procedural mechanisms that vary depending on the status of their claims and the amount 
6  of time since their examination by Dr. Chen.”  ECF No. 76 at 5.  
7      1.  Individuals with “Open” Claims 
8    “A class member who has an ‘open’ claim is an individual who received an unfavorable 
9  decision or determination of their claim but, as of the date of final approval of this Settlement 
10  Agreement, that decision or determination is not final.”  Id.   
11    For individuals who meet this definition, the ALJs handling their claims are required to: 
12  o  Notify the individual that he or she received a CE from Dr. Chen, and that Dr. Chen’s 
 
a
tr in
uoro 13  reports were flawed in important ways and subject to complaints, and that he is no longer 
Cfi
 tla
cC 14  allowed to perform these examinations; 
i
rts fo
iD tc 15  o  Notify the individual that he or she has the option to have the report from Dr. Chen 
 sir
et
tatsiD 16  excluded from consideration in the forthcoming adjudication; and 
S d nr
ee 17  o  Notify the individual that the adjudicator has the discretion to consider whether ordering an 
th
intr
Uo
N 18  additional CE is appropriate.  
19  ECF No. 76 at 5-6; ECF No. 76-1 at III.C.   
20    2.  Individuals with “Closed” Claims Who Were Examined by Dr. Chen 
21  On or After January 1, 2011 
22    “A class member who has a ‘closed’ claim is an individual who received an unfavorable 
23  decision or determination of their claim and, as of the date of final approval of this Settlement 
24  Agreement, that decision or determination is final.”  ECF No. 76 at 6; ECF No. 76-1 at III.A. 
25    Due to the fact that these class members’ claims are “closed,” if they are eligible for relief 
26  they will need to proceed through a readjudication process.  ECF No. 76 at 6.  “The person or 
27  entity responsible for readjudicating these claims will reflect the level at which each claimant 
28  received the unfavorable decision or determination.”  Id.   
9 

 
1    If the DDS made the final decision at issue, the proposed settlement provides that the SSA 
2  will readjudicate those claims through its “Disability Processing Unit,” without consideration of 
3  Dr. Chen’s CE report.  Id.; ECF No. 76-1 at III.A.2.a.  In addition to the omission of Dr. Chen’s 
4  report, the claimant will also have the opportunity to submit supplemental evidence relating to the 
5  previously-adjudicated period, and receive back benefits or payments if found to have been 
6  disabled for all, or any part of, the previously-adjudicated period.  Id.   
7    Moreover, if the Disability Processing Unit finds that the claimant was disabled at the end 
8  of the previously-adjudicated period, the claimant may use supplemental evidence or a new CE 
9  ordered by the Disability Processing Unit to show that his or her disability has continued beyond 
10  the previously adjudicated period, up to and including the date of readjudication.  Id.  A claimant 
11  who makes the appropriate showing will receive the appropriate additional back benefits or 
12  payments, and/or current benefits or payments.  Id. 
 
a
tr in
uoro 13    If an ALJ made the final decision at issue, a new hearing will be scheduled for 
Cfi
 tla
cC 14  reconsideration of the claim without consideration of Dr. Chen’s report.  ECF No. 76 at 7; ECF 
i
rts fo
iD tc 15  No. 76-1 at III.A.2.b.  A claimant in this category also has the opportunity to submit supplemental 
 sir
et
tatsiD 16  evidence relating to the previously-adjudicated period, the ALJ can order a new CE within his or 
S d nr
ee 17  her discretion, and the claimant will receive back benefits or payments if found to have been 
th
intr
Uo
N 18  disabled for all, or any part of, the previously-adjudicated period.  Id.  Furthermore, if the 
19  Disability Processing Unit finds that the claimant was disabled at the end of the previously-
20  adjudicated period, the claimant can show that his or her disability has continued beyond the 
21  previously adjudicated period, up to and including the date of the readjudication.  Id. Then, again, 
22  the claimant may use supplemental evidence and the ALJ can order a new CE in the exercise of 
23  his or her discretion.  Id.  If the claimant can make such a demonstration, he or she will receive the 
24  appropriate additional back benefits or payments, and/or current benefits or payments.  Id.   
25    If class members in this category requested review by the Appeals Council or if the 
26  Appeals Council took review on its own motion, their case will be remanded, and they will have a 
27  new hearing with the same rights described above.  Id.; ECF No. 76-1 at III.A.2.c.   
28      3.  Individuals With “Closed” Claims Who Were Examined by Dr. Chen 
10 

 
1  Between January 1, 2007 and December 31, 2010 
2    “A class member who has a ‘closed’ claim, and who was examined by Dr. Chen between 
3  January 1, 2007, and December 31, 2010, will be invited by SSA to apply for SSI or DIB benefits, 
4  or both, by timely returning a claim form, indicating on the form whether he or she is currently 
5  disabled, and proceeding to file a new application within the applicable timeframe.”  ECF No. 76; 
6  ECF No. 76-1 at III.B.2.  If the claimant is determined to be disabled upon adjudication of his or 
7  her current application, he or she will then be entitled to a “lookback assessment” for the 
8  previously-adjudicated period for which he or she were denied benefits.  Id.  The Disability 
9  Processing Unit will perform the lookback assessments based on the record without considering 
10  Dr. Chen’s report.  Again, the claimants are allowed to submit any relevant supplemental 
11  evidence.  Id.; ECF No. 76-1 at III.B.2.b.  A finding of disability during the previously-
12  adjudicated period will entitle the claimant to the appropriate award of back benefits or payments.  
 
a
tr in
uoro 13  ECF No. 76 at 8.  
Cfi
 tla
cC 14      4.  Individual in “Current Pay Status” 
i
rts fo
iD tc 15    Individuals in “current pay status” are currently receiving benefits, despite a past denial (or 
 sir
et
tatsiD 16  partial denial) of a claim for benefits that involved an examination by Dr. Chen.  Id.  “An 
S d nr
ee 17  individual who was already in ‘current pay status’ as of October 14, 2015—the date the Court 
th
intr
Uo
N 18  granted class certification—will not be eligible for relief.”  Id.   
19      5.  Individuals With Claims Where ALJ Explicitly Afforded No Weight to 
20  Dr. Chen’s Report 
21     “If SSA reviews the prior ALJ decision and determines that Dr. Chen’s CE report was 
22  explicitly afforded no weight in the analysis, that individual will not be eligible for another review 
23  of his or her claim.”  ECF No. 76 at 8; ECF No. 76-1 at III.A.2.b; III.A.2.c.   
24      6.  Individuals With “Closed” Claims Who Appealed to Federal Court 
25    For claimants eligible for relief who appealed their final decision to a federal court 
26  pursuant to 42 U.S.C. §§ 405(g) or 1383(c)(3) prior to the date of final approval and have a 
27  pending federal court case, “SSA will file a notice of non-opposition in response to a timely 
28  motion for remand to the agency for further proceedings if the claimant wishes to be eligible for 
11 

 
1  consideration for such relief.”  ECF No. 76 at 8; ECF No. 76-1 at III.A.2.d.  If a claimant is 
2  eligible for relief but his or her “federal court case has resulted in a final judgment affirming the 
3  final decision of the Commissioner, SSA will file a notice of non-opposition in response to a 
4  timely 60(b)(6) motion for remand to the agency for further proceedings if the claimant wishes to 
5  be eligible for consideration for such relief.”  ECF No. 76 at 8-9.   
6      7.  Additional Relief   
7    In addition to the relief discussed for each category of class member, Defendant will 
8  “begin a study of the processes through which it monitors the California DDS’s engagement, 
9  review, and retention of empaneled consultative examiners,” with the goal of identifying 
10  “mechanisms to improve the monitoring of these processes.”  ECF No. 76 at 9.  
11    Defendant has also “agreed to issue a document setting out processes for notifying 
12  adjudicators when an individual CE provider previously engaged by the California DDS has been 
 
a
tr in
uoro 13  disqualified for conduct determined to undermine the reliability of that provider’s reports.”  Id.; 
Cfi
 tla
cC 14  ECF No. 76-1 at IV.B.  “The document will also identify, to the extent feasible, processes for (1) 
i
rts fo
iD tc 15  providing notice to claimants with open claims, and their representatives, that they were examined 
 sir
et
tatsiD 16  by a disqualified provider and/or (2) providing new CEs to such claimants.”  Id.   
S d nr
ee 17    Defendants will also “pay attorney’s fees, both for pre-approval work already incurred and 
th
intr
Uo
N 18  for post-approval work in the future, and reimbursement of expenses and costs by Plaintiff’s 
19  counsel Justice in Aging and Legal Aid Society of San Mateo County in the amount of $490,000.”  
20  ECF No. 76 at 10; ECF No. 76-1 at VII.  “Plaintiffs’ counsel Morrison & Foerster has agreed to 
21  waive any attorney’s fees and costs incurred in connection with this action.”  Id.   
22    In exchange, “Plaintiffs agree to the dismissal of the Case with prejudice under Federal 
23  Rules of Civil Procedure 41(a)(1) and 23(e),” and agree to “release, waive, acquit, and forever 
24  discharge the United States, the Commissioner, the Social Security Administration, the California 
25  Disability Determination Service, and all of their officers, employees, and agents, from, and are 
26  hereby forever barred and precluded for prosecuting, any and all claims, causes of action, and/or 
27  requests for relief that would be barred by the doctrine of res judicata were final judgment on the 
28  merits entered on all claims asserted in this case.”  ECF No. 76-1 at VII-VIII.   
12 

 
1    D.  Analysis 
2    The Court concludes that the proposed benefits to be awarded to the class fall “within the 
3  range of possible approval.”   
4      1.  Risk, Expense, Complexity, and Likely Duration of Further Litigation 
5    While the parties agree that the outcome of a trial is “uncertain,” they do not describe 
6  Plaintiffs’ claims as “not particularly strong” or weak.  ECF No. 76 at 12; see also In re Bluetooth 
7  Headset Products Liability Litigation, 654 F.3d 935, 946 (9th Cir. 2011).  Still, the Court agrees 
8  that it would be more expensive and time-consuming for the parties to litigate this case through 
9  trial, and that resolution of this action through settlement is appropriate.  Discovery and an 
10  eventual trial would surely prolong the wait class members face to obtain relief.   
11      2.  Non-Collusive Negotiations 
12    In examining the means by which the parties arrived at a settlement, the Court concludes 
 
a
tr in
uoro 13  that the negotiations and agreement were non-collusive.  The stipulated settlement was reached 
Cfi
 tla
cC 14  after the parties engaged in motion practice and participated in arms-length, extensive settlement 
i
rts fo
iD tc 15  negotiations overseen by an experienced and neutral third party.  ECF No. 76 at 14.  These 
 sir
et
tatsiD 16  assertions support the conclusion that the settlement is non-collusive and likely to benefit the class 
S d nr
ee 17  members.  See, e.g., Harris v. Vector Marketing Corp., No. C-08-5198 EMC, 2011 WL 1627973, 
th
intr
Uo
N 18  at *8 (N.D. Cal. Apr. 29, 2011).  While no formal discovery has taken place, the parties exchanged 
19  some documents and information “that allowed the parties to draft and refine the terms of the 
20  Settlement Agreement,” and Plaintiffs’ own investigation resulted in useful documents that were 
21  included in the SSA’s prior filings.  Id. at 13; see In re Mego Fin. Corp. Sec. Litig., 213 F.3d 454, 
22  459 (9th Cir. 2000) (“[F]ormal discovery is not a necessary ticket to the bargaining table where the 
23  parties have sufficient information to make an informed decision about settlement.” (citations 
24  omitted)).  The Court also agrees that counsel for both Plaintiffs and Defendants are experienced 
25  and competent.  ECF No. 76 at 13. 
26      3.  Presence of a Government Participant 
27    Defendant Carolyn W. Colvin is Acting Commissioner of Social Security and is charged 
28  by federal law with administering and supervising the benefit programs administered by SSA.  
13 

 
1  The Court agrees that her participation weighs in favor of approval.  Id. at 14.    
2      4.  Obvious Deficiencies 
3    The settlement has no obvious deficiencies.  The settlement addresses Plaintiffs’ central 
4  claim by providing that class members will be afforded fair process to determine their eligibility 
5  for benefits without consideration of Dr. Chen’s reports.  It also allows some class members to 
6  preserve Dr. Chen’s report in their record by giving them the option of whether to challenge it.  
7  ECF No. 76 at 17.  The Court concludes that such relief falls within the range of possible 
8  approval.  
9      5.  Preferential Treatment 
10    Under this factor, the Court looks at whether the settlement agreement provides 
11  preferential treatment to any class member.  The named plaintiffs receive the same relief as all 
12  other class members under the agreement.  The variations that are included in the different sub-
 
a
tr in
uoro 13  classes reflect only that different class members occupy different procedural postures within 
Cfi
 tla
cC 14  SSA’s administrative process.  The Court agrees that the agreement provides relief through the use 
i
rts fo
iD tc 15  of procedural mechanisms most appropriate for each sub-group based on procedural posture.  
 sir
et
tatsiD 16  While such differences may result in different types of relief for the different subclasses, they are 
S d nr
ee 17  rational in this instance because some claimants’ claims are “closed” while others are “open,” and 
th
intr
Uo
N 18  the September 2011 distinguishing date represents when Defendant sent Dr. Chen a corrective 
19  action letter and was officially aware of problems with his reports.  See, e.g., Torrisi v. Tucson 
20  Elec. Power Co., 8 F.3d 1370, 1377 (9th Cir. 1993) (holding that two subclasses were rationally 
21  distinguished by events occurring on a certain date).  Thus, while Dr. Chen’s reports may well 
22  have been deficient before that date, class members for whom Dr. Chen prepared a report before 
23  September 2011 may require extra evidentiary support for their claims.  This distinction reflects a 
24  reasonable compromise.  
25      6.  Notice Procedure 
26    “Courts typically require less notice in Rule 23(b)(2) actions, as their outcomes do not 
27  truly bind class members.”   Lilly v. Jamba Juice Co., No. 13-cv-2998-JST, 2015 WL 1248027, at 
28  *8 (N.D. Cal. Mar. 18, 2015).  As the Supreme Court has stated, “[t]he Rule provides no 
14 

 
1  opportunity for (b)(1) or (b)(2) class members to opt out, and does not even oblige the District 
2  Court to afford them notice of the action.”  Wal-Mart Stores, Inc. v. Dukes, 564 U.S. 338, 362 
3  (2011).  Yet the Court “may direct appropriate notice to the class.”  Fed. R. Civ. P. 2(c)(2).   
4    When, for instance, “the settlement provides for only injunctive relief, and, therefore, there 
5  is no potential for the named plaintiffs to benefit at the expense of the rest of the class,” notice “is 
6  not uniformly required.”  Green v. Am. Express Co., 200 F.R.D. 211, 212-13 (S.D.N.Y. 2001).  
7  Such is the case here, as the settlement provides for injunctive relief and a readjudication process.  
8  Unlike in Lilly, however, in this case class members are releasing all of their claims in exchange 
9  for settlement relief.  Lilly, 2015 WL 1248027, at *8 (“[T]he settlement does not release the 
10  monetary claims of class members.”).  
11    In any case, the parties have proposed that notice be provided to the class.  This is wise, 
12  since class members’ will have to take affirmative action if they desire their claims to be reopened, 
 
a
tr in
uoro 13  and will subsequently be notified via the claim form procedure if the settlement agreement is 
Cfi
 tla
cC 14  finally approved.  First, notice is to be published, at Defendant’s expense, in three newspapers of 
i
rts fo
iD tc 15  general circulation.  ECF No. 76 at 18.  Plaintiffs’ counsel will also disseminate notice of the 
 sir
et
tatsiD 16  settlement to “several organizations that are likely to interact with class members,” and “provide 
S d nr
ee 17  adequate notice of the proposed class settlement so that interested parties may object to its 
th
intr
Uo
N 18  reasonableness.”  Id.  The Court agrees that individual notice of the settlement is not required 
19  because class members are not afforded an opportunity to opt out.  Fed. R. Civ. P. 23(c)(2).  In 
20  response to Plaintiffs’ request, the Court will order publication of this Publication Notice.   
21      7.  Claim Form Procedure 
22      If the Court approves the settlement agreement, the parties will send notice and 
23  corresponding “Request Forms” to “individual class members based on the relief afforded to 
24  them.”  ECF No. 76 at 19.  The Notice forms will be sent to class members’ last known address, 
25  will describe their procedural status within the SSA process, apprise them of the opportunity and 
26  risks associated with reopening their claims, advise claimants that they can have a representative 
27  help with his or her claim and that the claimant may want to speak to that representative before 
28  returning the request form, and includes an option to submit a different address.  Id.; ECF No. 76-
15 

 
1  1, Exh. A.  The Claim Forms require that class members return the forms within 30, 90, or 180 
2  days, depending on their subclass, if they wish for their claims to be reopened.  Id.  It is fair and 
3  reasonable to require claim forms to enable the class members to make a choice as to whether to 
4  reopen their claims. 
5  8.  Notice Provision for Objections 
6  The Notice of Settlement contains a section entitled, “What Can You Do If You Object To 
7  The Settlement Or Have Other Comments?”  ECF No. 76-1 at 76.  Consistent with the Northern 
8  District’s Procedural Guidance for Class Action Settlements, 
9  http://www.cand.uscourts.gov/ClassActionSettlementGuidance, the parties are ordered to amend 
10  that section of the Notice to read as follows: 
 
11  You can ask the Court to deny approval by filing an objection.  You can’t ask the 
Court to order a larger or different settlement; the Court can only approve or deny 
  12  the settlement.  If the Court denies approval, no relief will be awarded to the class 
a
tr in and the lawsuit will continue.  If that is what you want to happen, you must object. 
uoro 13   
Cfi
 tla You may object to the proposed settlement in writing.  You may also appear at the 
ciC 14  Final Approval Hearing, either in person or through your own attorney.  If you 
rts fo appear through your own attorney, you are responsible for paying that attorney.  All 
iD tc 15  written objections and supporting papers must (a) clearly identify the case name 
 sir
et and number (Hart v. Colvin, Case Number 3:15-cv-00623-JST), (b) be submitted to 
tatsiD 16  the Court either by mailing them to the Class Action Clerk, United States District 
S d nr Court for the Northern District of California, 450 Golden Gate Avenue, San 
ee 17  Francisco, CA 94102, or by filing them in person at any location of the United 
th
intr States District Court for the Northern District of California, and (c) be filed or 
Uo
N 18  postmarked on or before February 10, 2017.” 
19  CONCLUSION 
20  The Motion for Preliminary Approval of Class Action Settlement Agreement is granted.  
21  The Court therefore orders as follows: 
22  1.  The Court preliminarily approves the agreement set forth in the Settlement 
23  Agreement.  See ECF No. 76-1.    
24  2.  The class certified in the Court’s prior order, ECF No. 50, is modified to be defined 
25  as follows: 
26 
[A]ll persons whose SSI or SSDI benefits were either denied or terminated and for 
whom a consultative examination was prepared by Dr. Frank Chen, and all persons 
27 
who received a partially favorable decisions or determination on their claim for SSI 
or SSDI benefits and for whom a consultative examination was prepared by Dr.

16 

 
Chen.

  3.  The Court sets the following dates and deadlines:

rts fo

1 Plaintiffs, Kevin Hart, Nina Silva-Collins, and Lee Harris, on behalf of themselves and all 
2 others similarly situated, and Defendant, Nancy A. Berryhill, Acting Commissioner of Social 
3 Security, sued solely in her official capacity (“SSA”), submit this Stipulated Request to Amend 
4 the Court’s April 17, 2017 Order Granting Final Approval of Class Action Settlement (“Order”) 
5 [ECF  No.  88]  to  comport  with  the  terms  of  the  parties’  Amended  Settlement  Agreement 
6 (“Agreement”) [ECF No. 79-1].  The April 17, 2017 Order differs from the Agreement in the 
7 following four material respects.  First, on page 1, line 19, the Order recites that the case involves 
8 “evidence used by Administrative Law Judges (‘ALJs’),” but the case involved adjudications at 
9 all levels, not just at the ALJ stage, so Plaintiff would request that “Administrative Law Judges 
10 (‘ALJs’)” be replaced with “Social Security Administration (‘SSA’)”; and at page 1, line 20-21, 
instead of saying “The evidence ALJs consider when making a disability benefits determination 
11
includes consultative evaluations,”  this should be re[placed with “The evidence the agency 
12
considers when making a disability benefits determination often includes consultative evaluations 
13
… . “   Second, the Order sets the date for mailing Request Forms as May 19, 2017, but under the 
14
Agreement that the Court was approving, the deadline for mailing the Request Forms is later, 
15
namely, ninety days (for most forms) and twenty days (for another form) after the time for any 
16
appeals from the approval order has elapsed.  Third, the Order contains language that might create 
17
confusion concerning the enforcement mechanism negotiated and agreed upon by the parties.  
18
Fourth, the parties had requested that the Court grant final approval to the amended class 
19
definition, which was omitted from the Court’s Order Granting Final Approval.  Respectfully, 
20
therefore, the parties request that the Court amend its April 17, 2017 Order in the manner 
21
described below.  Alternatively, the parties request that the Court withdraw the Order and enter 
22
the Amended Proposed Order [ECF No. 85-1] that the parties submitted on March 1, 2017 in 
23
connection with Plaintiffs’ Motion for Final Approval.   
24
Request for Amendment of the Order 
25
  The Conclusion of the Order provides as follows: 
26
 
27
CONCLUSION 
28
Hart, et al. v. Berryhill, Case No. 3:15-cv-00623-JST 
Stipulated Request to Amend Order Granting Final Approval  1 

Case 3:15-cv-00623-JST   Document 90   Filed 04/25/17   Page 4 of 10
 
The Court finds the settlement agreement fair, adequate, and 
1
reasonable and GRANTS Plaintiffs motion for final approval of the 
settlement. 
2
The parties shall distribute the Request Forms by May 19, 
3 2017. 
Defendant will pay $490,000 in attorneys’ fees and costs to 
4
Plaintiffs’ counsel Justice in Aging and Legal Aid Society of San 
Mateo County. The Court finds that this award is fair and reasonable 
5
in light of the nature of this Action, counsel’s experience and efforts 
6 in prosecuting and resolving this action, and the benefits obtained 
for  the  Class.  Plaintiffs’  co-counsel,  Morrison  &  Foerster,  has 
7
agreed to waive its fees and costs. 
8 The Court reserves exclusive and continuing jurisdiction 
over the Action, the Class Representatives, the Class members, and 
9 Defendants for the purposes of supervising the implementation, 
enforcement, and construction of the Settlement and this Judgment. 
10
 
11
Order 5.  The parties request that the Order be amended to remove the second and fourth 
12
paragraphs of this Conclusion, and to include a term that the parties had requested that the Court 
13
include.   
14
Second Paragraph: In the Agreement, the parties did not establish a date certain (such as 
15
May 19, 2017) by which SSA would send claimants the agreed-upon notices and claim forms 
16
(referred to by the Court as “Request Forms” in the Order).  Instead, the deadline to send such 
17
forms is to be established in relation to the “date on which the Settlement becomes effective.”  
18
See Agreement 18, 20, 27, 28, 31 (providing that SSA will send Notices A, A2, B, and B2 within 
19
ninety days after the effective date and Notice C within twenty days after the effective date).  
20
Pursuant to the agreed definition, the “date on which the Settlement becomes effective” will not 
21
be known until either (1) any timely appeal of the approval order is resolved; or (2) no timely 
22
appeal is filed.  Agreement 4 (defining “date on which the Settlement becomes effective”).  A 
23
May 19, 2017 deadline to distribute the Request Forms is therefore at odds with the terms of the 
24
Agreement.  Further, counsel have been informed that SSA is not in a position to meet a May 19, 
25
2017 deadline (which would in any event come before the deadline for an appeal from the April 
26
17, 2017 Order).  Therefore, the parties respectfully request that the second paragraph of the 
27
Conclusion be stricken.  Otherwise, the parties will be in the difficult position of having an Order 
28
Hart, et al. v. Berryhill, Case No. 3:15-cv-00623-JST 
Stipulated Request to Amend Order Granting Final Approval  2 

Case 3:15-cv-00623-JST   Document 90   Filed 04/25/17   Page 5 of 10
 
1 granting final approval of a Settlement Agreement that deviates from the negotiated terms of the 
2 Settlement Agreement (and which, as a practical matter, cannot be performed).  
3 Fourth Paragraph: In the Agreement, the parties identified specific pre-dispute resolution 
4 procedures in an Enforcement provision.  Agreement 33-35. Without noting the Enforcement 
5 provision, the April 17, 2017 Order states that the Court “reserves exclusive and continuing 
6 jurisdiction over the Action, the Class Representatives, the Class members, and Defendants for 
7 the purposes of supervising the implementation, enforcement, and construction of the Settlement 
8 and this Judgment.”  Order 5.    In the Agreement, however, the parties agreed to an “exclusive 
9 process for remedying alleged violations of this Agreement.”  Agreement 33.  The parties “further 
agree[d] that no other litigation action in the Case, including but not limited to the filing of any 
10
motions  or  pleadings,  may  be  taken  except  as  set  forth  in  this  Section  VI  [concerning 
11
Enforcement].”  Id.  In order to avoid potential confusion from the language in the Order (which 
12
does not expressly reference the Enforcement provision), the parties respectfully request that the 
13
fourth paragraph of the Conclusion be stricken.1  
14
Final Approval of Amended Class Definition: In the Agreement, the parties agreed, for 
15
settlement purposes, to amend the definition of the class and to request that the Court amend the 
16
certified class so that the plaintiff class is defined as consisting of “all persons whose SSI or SSDI 
17
benefits were either denied or terminated and for whom a consultative examination was prepared 
18
by Dr. Frank Chen, and all persons who received a partially favorable decision or determination 
19
on their claim for SSI or SSDI benefits and for whom a consultative examination was prepared 
20
by Dr. Chen.”  Agreement 6-7.  Although the Court preliminarily approved this modification of 
21
the class definition, see Order Granting Mot. for Prelim. Approval, ECF No. 81, at 6-7, it did not 
22
expressly grant final approval to this modification.  To ensure that proper notice is given of the 
23
                            
24  
1 It appears that the fourth paragraph of the Conclusion may have been drawn from the 
25
original proposed order submitted by Plaintiffs in connection with their Motion for Final 
Approval.  See Proposed Order, ECF No. 82-3, at 5, ¶ 10 (using same language as fourth 
26
paragraph of the Conclusion).  Following submission of this proposed order, SSA registered its 
27 objections to this language with Plaintiffs’ counsel, and the parties then agreed to submit an 
Amended Proposed Order, in which this language does not appear.  See Notice of Am. Proposed 
28
Order, ECF No. 85-1; see also Def.’s Mem. Supp. Final Approval, ECF No. 83, at 1 n.2. 
Hart, et al. v. Berryhill, Case No. 3:15-cv-00623-JST 
Stipulated Request to Amend Order Granting Final Approval  3 

Case 3:15-cv-00623-JST   Document 90   Filed 04/25/17   Page 6 of 10
 
1 amended class definition, and out of an abundance of caution, the parties respectfully request that 
2 the Court add a new paragraph to the Conclusion granting final approval to the amended class 
3 definition.  See also Notice of Am. Proposed Order, ECF No. 85-1, at 1-2, ¶ 5. 
4 *  *  * 
5 In summary, the parties respectfully request that the Court amend page 1, line 19 to replace 
6 “Administrative Law Judges (‘ALJs’)” with “Social Security Administration (‘SSA’)”; and at 
7 page 1, line 20-21, instead of saying “The evidence ALJs consider when making a disability 
8 benefits determination includes consultative evaluations,” this should be replaced with “The 
9 evidence the agency considers when making a disability benefits determination often includes 
consultative evaluations … . “   The Conclusion of the Order should be amended so that it provides 
10
as follows: 
11
 
12
CONCLUSION 
13
The Court finds the settlement agreement fair, adequate, and 
reasonable and GRANTS Plaintiffs motion for final approval of the 
14
settlement. 
15 This Court gives its final approval of the Settlement to the 
amended class definition as approved in its Order Granting Motion 
16
for Preliminary Approval of Class Action Settlement: 
[A]ll persons whose SSI or SSDI benefits 
17
were either denied or terminated and for whom a 
18 consultative examination was prepared by Dr. Frank 
Chen,  and  all  persons  who  received  a  partially 
19
favorable decision or determination on their claim 
for SSI or SSDI benefits and for whom a consultative 
20
examination was prepared by Dr. Chen. 
21 (ECF No. 81 at 6-7.)
